revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox writer <!-- For more information see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]]. --> | name = Gail Godwin | image = File:Gail Godwin headshot.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = Gail Kathleen Godwin | birth_date = June 18, 1937 | birth_place = Birmingham, Alabama | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = Author | language = | nationality = | ethnicity = | citizenship = American | education = {{plainlist| * Bachelor's in Journalism, University of North Carolina * M.A. Ph.D., University of Iowa }} | period = | genre = Fiction, autobiography | subject = | movement = | notableworks = ''A Mother and Two Daughters'' (1982); ''A Southern Family'' (1987) | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards =Three-time National Book Award nominee | signature = | signature_alt = | website = {{URL|http://www.gailgodwin.com/}} }} '''Gail Godwin''' (born June 18, 1937) is an American [[novelist]] and [[short story]] writer. Godwin has written 14 novels, two short story collections, three non-fiction books, and ten [[libretti]]. Her primary literary accomplishments are her novels, which have included five best-sellers and three finalists for the [[National Book Award]]. Most of her books are realistic fiction novels that follow a character's psychological and intellectual development, often based on themes taken from Godwin's own life.
Godwin was born in [[Birmingham, Alabama]], but raised mostly in [[Asheville, North Carolina]] by her mother and grandmother. She adopted her mother's interest in writing at an early age and obtained a Bachelor's degree in journalism from the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] (UNC). After graduating, she worked briefly as a reporter for ''[[The Miami Herald]]'', then traveled to Europe and worked for the [[U.S. Travel Service]] run by the [[Embassy of the United States in London|U.S. Embassy in London]]. She returned to the U.S. after six years. Godwin taught English at the [[University of Iowa]], while earning her M.A. (1968) and PhD (1971) in [[English Literature]].
While at the University of Iowa, Godwin's dissertation became her first novel, ''The Perfectionists''. By 1976 she had become a successful writer and author of three books. In particular, two books written by her in the 1980s, ''A Mother and Two Daughters'' (1982) and ''A Southern Family'' (1987), resulted in further acclaim and expanded the readership of her books. Following ''The Finishing School'' (1984), readership of her books dramatically declined until 2006, when ''Queen of the Underworld'' was published. ''Flora'' (2013) became one of her more commercially successful novels.
==Early life and family== [[File:Gail Godwin Age 3.jpg|thumb|left|Gail Godwin at three years of age]]Gail Godwin was born on June 18, 1937 in [[Birmingham, Alabama]].<ref name="one"/> Her parents, Kathleen Krahenbuhl and Mose Winston Godwin, were both from North Carolina, but visiting cousins in Alabama when Godwin was born.<ref name="Dyer 2000 p. ">{{cite book | last=Dyer | first=Joyce | title=Bloodroot : Reflections on Place by Appalachian Women Writers | publisher=University Press of Kentucky | location=Lexington | year=2000 | isbn=0-8131-0983-3 | page=}}</ref> Godwin's parents divorced two years later.<ref name="two">{{cite book | last =Decker | first =Jeffrey| authorlink = | title =Dictionary of Literary Biography | publisher =Gale | series =2 | volume =350 | edition = | date =2009 | location = | isbn =978-0-8103-7579-6 }}</ref> After the breakup, Gail and her mother moved in with her grandparents in [[Durham, North Carolina]]. They moved again to [[Weaverville, NC]] and then to Asheville, NC.<ref name="sixteen">{{cite book | last =Hill | first =Jane | title =Gail Godwin | publisher =Twayne Publishers | date =1992 | isbn = }}</ref> Her grandfather died in 1939,<ref name="sixteen"/> so Godwin was raised by her mother and grandmother in Asheville, where they lived until 1948.<ref name="one"/><ref name="two"/>
Godwin's grandmother filled the traditional role of a mother, cleaning, cooking and sewing, while her mother was the [[Breadwinner model|breadwinner]].<ref name="one"/><ref name="two"/> Godwin's mother had a Bachelor's and master's degree from [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]]. She taught college-level English in the mornings, and worked as a reporter for a local paper, ''[[Asheville Citizen-Times]]'', in the evenings. On the weekends she wrote love stories for magazines in New York.<ref name="one"/> According to Godwin, growing up with two female guardians had an influence on her writing and her decision to become a writer.<ref name="one"/> By age five she had started identifying with her mother's occupation as a writer more so than her grandmother's work.<ref name="one"/> At nine years old Godwin wrote her first story, titled "Ollie McGonnigle".<ref name="one"/><ref name="Manning 1993 p. 259">{{cite book | last=Manning | first=C.S. | title=The Female Tradition in Southern Literature | publisher=University of Illinois Press | year=1993 | isbn=978-0-252-06444-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eo8J0NELAhkC&pg=PA259 | accessdate=October 28, 2015 | page=259}}</ref>
[[File:Gail Godwin (age 13) with Mother Kathleen Cole.jpg|thumb|right|Gail Godwin at age 13 with her mother]]In 1948 Kathleen married Frank Cole, a [[World War II]] veteran, and moved the family to Virginia.<ref name="one"/><ref name="sixteen"/> Godwin was further inspired by her mother's determination to continue writing after having a second child.<ref name="one"/> According to Godwin, much of her time growing up was spent in the newsroom, where her mother worked.<ref name="four">{{cite news|first=Tony|last=Brown|title=Coming Home|newspaper=The Ashville Citizen|date=October 21, 1980}}</ref> She also witnessed her mother's plays and novels being rejected. Godwin's autobiography creates the impression that much of her own writing was intended to accomplish the things her mother could not.<ref name="Smith 2015"/> As Cole's salary increased and he was able to support the family, Godwin's mother focused on being a wife and homemaker, eventually not writing at all.<ref name="sixteen"/>
In Godwin's late teens, her stepfather was working as a salesman and the family moved often. Godwin attended several different high schools,<ref name="HISTORY.com 1937">{{cite web | title=Novelist Gail Godwin is born - Jun 18, 1937 | website=HISTORY.com | date=June 18, 1937 | url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/novelist-gail-godwin-is-born | accessdate=August 14, 2015}}</ref> including an all-girls Catholic school, [[Carolina Day School|St. Genevieve-of-the-Pines]].<ref name="two"/> It was Godwin's favorite teacher at St. Genevieve-of-the-Pines who persuaded her to start keeping a personal diary.<ref name="Schwabe 2013">{{cite web | last=Schwabe | first=Liesl | title=Past, Present: Gail Godwin | website=PublishersWeekly.com | date=March 22, 2013 | url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/authors/profiles/article/56477-past-present-gail-godwin.html | accessdate=August 24, 2015}}</ref> According to Godwin, she had a "church upbringing or convent school training."<ref>{{cite book|title=A Spiritual Life: Perspectives from Poets, Prophets, and Preachers|first=Gail|last=Godwin|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|date=2011}}</ref> She attended church at St. Mary's and All Souls.<ref name="ten"/> She also wrote a short novel as a teenager.<ref name="one"/>
Godwin had no relationship with her father, until the two re-connected at her high school graduation.<ref name="two"/> Godwin's father then offered to pay for her college education.<ref name="HISTORY.com 1937"/> During her junior year in college, Godwin moved in with her father, who committed suicide later that year.<ref name="ChampionAustin">{{cite book | last=Champion | first=L. | last2=Austin | first2=R. | title=Contemporary American Women Fiction Writers: An A-to-Z Guide | publisher=Greenwood Press | year=2002 | isbn=978-0-313-31627-2 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2FGahwDJFu4C&pg=PA102 | accessdate=August 20, 2015 | pages=163–165}}</ref> Godwin's uncle{{efn|Her uncle's obituary says he died in the hospital after suffering a stroke<ref>{{cite news|title=William I. Godwin Dies|date=April 13, 1976|newspaper=Smithfield Herald Times}}</ref>}} and a half brother later committed suicide as well.<ref name="two"/> Her mother died in a car accident<ref name="seven"/> in 1989.<ref name="sixteen"/>
Godwin attended [[William Peace University|Peace College]] in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]] from 1955 to 1957. She then transferred to [[University of North Carolina]] (UNC), where she attended from 1957 to 1959, graduating with a bachelor's degree in journalism.<ref name="one"/><ref name="three"/> While in college she worked on ''The Otherwise Virgins'', a novel her mother had written, but was unable to find a publisher for.<ref name="one"/> In 1959 Knopf sent an agent to UNC to scout young writers. Godwin submitted a portion of her novel ''Windy Peaks'' for their consideration. The story was about the staff and guests at a resort hotel in the mountains. Her manuscript was rejected.<ref name="Smith 2015"/><ref name="Fabrega 2015">{{cite web | last=Fabrega | first=Meganne | title=Review: 'Publishing: A Writer's Memoir,' by Gail Godwin | website=Star Tribune | date=January 17, 2015 | url=http://www.startribune.com/review-publishing-a-writer-s-memoir-by-gail-godwin/288760561/ | accessdate=August 14, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Citizen Times 2015">{{cite web | title=Rob Neufeld: Godwin reveals publishing world and more | website=Citizen Times | date=January 10, 2015 | url=http://www.citizen-times.com/story/life/books/2015/01/10/rob-neufeld-godwin-reveals-publishing-world/21549311/ | accessdate=August 14, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Godwin">{{cite book | last=Godwin | first=Gail | title=Publishing A Writer's Memoir | publisher=Audible Studios on Brilliance audio | location=City | year=2015 | isbn=1-5012-7728-6 | page=}}</ref> Godwin also worked as a waitress at Mayview Manor at [[Blowing Rock, North Carolina]] during her sophomore and junior years.<ref name="seven"/>
==Early work== Godwin's first job out of college was at ''[[The Miami Herald]]'', where she worked as a journalist for one year. There she met and briefly married photographer and co-worker, Douglas Kennedy.<ref name="one"/><ref name="two"/> They were married in 1960 and divorced several months later in 1961.<ref name="two"/><ref name="Godwin"/> According to Godwin, she "worked very hard", but her stories were too "flamboyant" for the publication and she was fired.<ref name="three"/> According to ''Contemporary Literary Criticism'', she was incorporating too much human interest into the paper's stories, which were supposed to be factual.<ref name="twothousand"/> After briefly living with her mother again,<ref name="sixteen"/> Godwin moved to London to distance herself from a failed marriage and job.<ref name="six">{{cite news|title=The Clef to the Roman|date=March 5, 2006|first=Liesl|last=Schillinger|newspaper=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/05/books/review/05schillinger.html?n=Top%2FFeatures%2FBooks%2FBook%20Reviews&_r=0|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref>
In London Godwin worked for the [[U.S. Travel Service]] run by the American [[embassy]]<ref name="one"/> from 1961 to 1965.<ref name="sixteen"/> Godwin said she was a "glorified receptionist," who was able to read books in secret while at work.<ref name="three"/> Her cousin, who was the mayor of [[Weaverville, North Carolina]], helped to get her the job.<ref name="Godwin"/> While she was employed by the embassy, Godwin completed a novel entitled ''Gull Key''. Like many of her early works, the book focuses on a female character figuring out if marriage and being a parent is the life she wants for herself. Several publishers rejected the novel and the manuscript was lost when Godwin sent the only copy to a publisher that went out of business without returning it.<ref name="one"/><ref name="Godwin"/>
While in England, Godwin took a course in creative writing at the City Literature Institute, where she met her second husband, psychiatrist Ian Marshall.<ref name="one"/> They were married two months later.<ref name="sixteen"/> The marriage was brief and they were divorced in 1966.<ref name="one">{{cite book | last1 =Flora | first1 =Joseph|last2=Bain|first2=Robert | authorlink = | title =Contemporary Fiction Writers of the South| publisher =Greenwood | date = August 23, 1993 | location = | pages =193–201| isbn = 978-0-313-28764-0}}</ref><ref name="two"/> After their breakup, Godwin returned to the United States.<ref name="one"/> At age 29, she took a job as fact-checker in [[New York City]] for ''[[The Saturday Evening Post]]''. She said the job was embarrassing, because she wanted to be a writer, as opposed to fact-checking the work of others.<ref name="three"/>
At this point, a distant uncle of Godwin's died, leaving her an inheritance of $5,000.<ref name="seven">{{cite news|date=October 16, 1994|newspaper=The Charlotte Observer|title=Love and Order|first=Dannye|last=Powell}}</ref> She used the money to apply to the [[Iowa Writers Workshop]] and, after being accepted, to move from New York to [[Iowa City]] in 1967.<ref name="sixteen"/><ref name="three"/> There Godwin met her teacher and future mentor [[Kurt Vonnegut]].<ref name="sixteen"/> At Iowa, Godwin worked as an instructor while earning an M.A. and Ph.D. from the same university in 1968 and 1971 respectively.<ref name="one"/><ref name="twothousand"/> She began teaching [[Greek Drama]], before earning a position teaching literature.<ref name="one"/><ref name="Godwin"/> By age 30, Godwin had written three novels, but was unable to get any of them published.<ref name="Smith 2015"/>
==Author==
===Early published work=== According to ''The Asheville Citizen-Times'', Godwin's first successful work was a 1969 short story in ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]''.<ref name="four"/> Her first published novel was her [[dissertation]] written as graduate work at University of Iowa. It was published in 1970 and called ''The Perfectionists''.<ref name="two"/> The story was based loosely on Godwin's second marriage. It was accepted by [[Harper & Row]] in December 1968,<ref name="Smith 2015"/> while Godwin completing her graduate work.<ref name="sixteen"/> From 1971 on, Godwin earned a living through her work as a writer and augmented her income by means of intermittent teaching positions.<ref name="sixteen"/>
[[File:Gail & Robert's Woodstock House.jpg|thumb|right|The house in Woodstock, New York, where Godwin completed many of her books]]After completing her graduate work in 1971, Godwin spent two months at the [[Yaddo#Artists.27 colony|Yaddo artist's colony]] in Upstate New York in 1972. There she wrote 100 pages of a novel called ''The Villain'', which was never published. The work was scrapped, but ended up being part of the basis for ''The Odd Woman''.<ref name="sixteen"/> According to author Jane Hill, it was while working on ''The Odd Women'' that Godwin transitioned from linear narratives to more complex structures where the plot interweaves past and present events.<ref name="two"/><ref name="sixteen"/>
It was at Yaddo that Godwin met composer Robert Starer and began a life partnership with him that lasted until his death in 2001.<ref name="two"/><ref name="twelve"/> They moved to [[Stone Ridge, New York]] in 1973<ref name="Godwin"/> and later built a house in [[Woodstock, New York]], where Godwin continued her work from home.<ref name="two"/><ref name="twelve"/> In addition to her books and short stories, Godwin wrote [[libretti]] for ten of Starer's musical compositions.<ref name="two"/>
===Height of Godwin's career=== By 1976 Godwin was a successful writer and novelist who had published three books: ''The Perfectionists'', ''Glass People'', and ''The Odd Woman''.<ref name="three"/> ''The Odd Woman'' was the longest and most widely recognized of the three.<ref name="four"/> Several short stories by Godwin were published in prominent magazines like Harper's Esquire, [[Ms.]] and the [[Paris Review]], where she was often featured on the cover.<ref name="three">{{cite news|newspaper=The Charlotte Observer|date=February 20, 1976|title=Gail Godwin: She's a Writer at the Core}}</ref> Godwin was awarded grants from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] (1975–76) and the [[John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation]] (1975–76).<ref name="one"/>
Throughout her career, Godwin worked consistently with her agent, John Hawkins, but worked with several different publishing houses.<ref name="nine">{{cite news|newspaper=Publishers Weekly|date=February 15, 1999|title=The Good Husband}}</ref> Godwin's early books were published by [[Alfred A. Knopf|Knopf]].<ref name="nine"/> After the editor for ''The Perfectionists'', David Segal, died suddenly of a heart attack, [[Robert Gottlieb]] from Knopf became her editor for her next four books.<ref name="one"/><ref name="Godwin"/> Godwin credits Gottlieb for much of the success of her early works.<ref name="Smith 2015"/> Later on, when Godwin's then-recent books were less widely read, ''USA Today'' commented that this could be in part because she was no longer working with Gottlieb.<ref name="Godwin 2015"/> After Knopf, Godwin contracted with [[Viking]], who offered larger advances and more publicity for her books.<ref name="Godwin"/><ref name="Kirkusone">{{cite web | last=Godwin | first=Gail | website=Kirkus Reviews | date=November 1, 2014 | url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/gail-godwin/publishing/ | title=Publishing|accessdate=September 18, 2015}}</ref>
During the years 1982 to 1991, Godwin produced another collection of short fiction and four more novels.<ref name="one"/> According to ''Publishers Weekly'', it was ''A Mother and Two Daughters'' (1982) and ''A Southern Family'' (1987) that substantially expanded her readership. These novels remained on bestseller lists for an extended period of time.<ref name="twelve">{{cite news|title=Gail Godwin: A Leap of Faith in a New Novel|newspaper=Publishers Weekly|date=February 15, 1999|first=John|last=Baker}}</ref> Godwin's earlier works had sold an average of less than 8,000 copies, while ''A Mother and Two Daughters'' sold more than 1.5 million.<ref name="sixteen"/> It was the most popular of Godwin's early works<ref name="ChampionAustin"/> and the first time she had written a narrative from the point-of-view of multiple characters.<ref name="sixteen"/><ref name="alpha"/> In 1987, Godwin was awarded the [[Janet Heidinger Kafka Prize]] for her work on ''The Southern Family''.<ref name="University of Rochester">{{cite web | title=Kafka Recipients : Susan B. Anthony Institute for Gender & Women's Studies : University of Rochester | website=University of Rochester | url=http://www.rochester.edu/college/wst/SBAI/recipients.html | accessdate=October 28, 2015}}</ref><ref name="May Magill 2001">{{cite book | last=May | first=C.E. | last2=Magill | first2=F.N. | title=Critical Survey of Short Fiction: James T. Farrell - W.W. Jacobs | publisher=Salem Press | series=Critical Survey Series | year=2001 | isbn=978-0-89356-009-6 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TJojAQAAIAAJ | accessdate=October 28, 2015}}</ref>
By the early 2000s, five of Godwin's books had made the [[The New York Times Best Seller list|New York Times Bestsellers List]] and three were finalists for the National Book Award.<ref name="National Book Awards, 2008">{{cite web | title=Judges' Bios - The National Book FoundationThe National Book Foundation | website=National Book Awards, 2008 | url=http://www.nationalbook.org/nba2008_judges_bios.html#.VeobD51VhHx | accessdate=September 4, 2015}}</ref><ref name="latimes 2006"/><ref name="Smith 2014">{{cite web | last=Smith | first=Claiborne | title=From the Editor's Desk: Choose Your Nostalgia Wisely | website=Kirkus Reviews | date=November 1, 2014 | url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/features/editors-desk-choose-your-nostalgia-wisely/ | accessdate=September 18, 2015}}</ref>
===Recent works=== By 1999 Godwin had published ten novels.<ref name="thirteen">{{cite news|date=March 14, 1999|title=Understated lives well-lived|newspaper=The Charlotte Observer}}</ref> In 2001, Godwin's partner, [[Robert Starer]], died and she began writing a fictional story based on their life called ''Evenings at Five'' that was published two years later.<ref name="Narrative Magazine 2009">{{cite web | title=Gail Godwin |first=Pia|last=Ehrhardt| website=Narrative Magazine | date=January 3, 2009 | url=http://www.narrativemagazine.com/issues/winter-2010/gail-godwin-an-interview | accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref> In November 2004 Godwin signed a contract with the publisher [[Ballantine Books]] for her next four books.<ref name="ProQuest 2015">http://search.proquest.com/docview/197072836</ref>
[[File:Gail Godwin at Pawley's Island Writing The Finishing School (1983).jpg|thumb|left|Gail Godwin writing ''The Finishing School'' on a typewriter in 1983.]]According to ''Publishers Weekly'', Godwin had "achieved a huge degree of success" and still had many devoted readers, but by 1999 she was "no longer the draw she once was."<ref name="nine"/> By 2006 ''The Finishing School'' (1984) was her last major, commercially successful book, which was followed by a drop in readership.<ref name="Godwin 2015">{{cite web | last=Godwin | first=Gail | title=Gail Godwin Recalls Her Years in 'Publishing' | website=USA TODAY | date=January 17, 2015 | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/books/2015/01/17/publishing-a-writers-memoir/21802343/ | accessdate=August 14, 2015}}</ref><ref name="latimes 2006"/> According to Godwin, she was "one of the many authors to be caught in the tumult while [the publishing industry] thrashed about in search of a new business model."<ref name="Kirkusone"/> ''The Los Angeles Times'' said her characters that were progressive working women in the 1970s and 1980s, were now considered "tame" in a modern context.<ref name="latimes 2006">{{cite news| first=Susan|last=Reynolds|title=A Double Dose of Bestseller Gail Godwin | newspaper=Los Angeles Times| date=January 24, 2006 | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/jan/24/entertainment/et-godwin24 | accessdate=August 24, 2015}}</ref>
''Kirkus Reviews'' said Godwin had "a couple of subpar efforts," until publishing ''Queen of the Underworld'' in 2006.<ref name="Narrative Magazine 2009"/><ref name="Godwin 2014">{{cite web | last=Godwin | first=Gail | website=Kirkus Reviews | date=November 1, 2014 | url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/gail-godwin/unfinished-desires/ | accessdate=September 18, 2015|title=Unfinished Desires}}</ref> ''Flora'' (2013) became one of her better selling books.<ref name="Wood 2014">{{cite web | last=Wood | first=Lucy | title=What's Essential | website=Kirkus Reviews | date=November 1, 2014 | url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/features/whats-essential/ | accessdate=September 18, 2015}}</ref> Godwin also authored an autobiography, ''Publishing'' that appeared in 2015.<ref name="Smith 2015"/> The ''Los Angeles Times'' said her auto-biography was a "preemptive strike" after she was approached by an independent biographer.<ref name="latimes 2006"/> As of 2015, Godwin's published works have included 14 novels, two collections of short stories, three non-fiction works, and ten libretti.<ref name="Smith 2015">{{cite web | last=Smith | first=Dinitia | title=For Gail Godwin, the Prose Was the Easy Part | newspaper=The Wall Street Journal | date=January 26, 2015 | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/book-review-publishing-by-gail-godwin-1422316084 | accessdate=August 13, 2015}}</ref>
===Academia and other work=== According to ''The Intellectual in Twentieth-Century Southern Literature'', Godwin was unusual in that she was a popular novelist that was also working in academia.<ref name="Powell 2012 p. 178"/> Godwin taught at the [[University of Illinois]] Center for Advanced Studies from 1971 to 1972.<ref name="five">{{cite news|title=Gail Godwin and Friends to Get Together|first=Rick|last=Gunter|newspaper=The Asheville Citizen|date=September 30, 1982}}</ref> During her time as an author, she was also a lecturer at the Iowa Writers' Workshop (1972 to 1973), [[Vassar College]] (1977), and [[Columbia University]] (1978/1981).<ref name="sixteen"/><ref name="ChampionAustin"/><ref name="Powell 2012 p. 178"/> She acted as chair of the fiction panel for the [[National Book Awards]] in 1986<ref name="sixteen"/> and 2008.<ref name="National Book Foundation, Presenter of the National Book Awards, www.nationalbook.org">{{cite web | title=2008 National Book Awards Winners and Finalists, The National Book Foundation | website=National Book Foundation, Presenter of the National Book Awards, www.nationalbook.org | url=https://www.nationalbook.org/awards-prizes/national-book-awards-2008#.VehinZ1VhHw | accessdate=September 3, 2015}}</ref> In 1989, Godwin also founded a small publishing house called St. Hilda's Press. It published religious texts not printed by more commercialized publishers.<ref name="sixteen"/><ref name="nine"/> She later became a Distinguished Alumna of the University of North Carolina and the University of Iowa.<ref name="two"/>
==Themes== Most of Godwin's works are based on themes or events taken from her own life.<ref name="one"/> The characters, settings and narratives vary from novel-to-novel, but common topics have included family, the position of women in society and relationships, a woman's artistic and career pursuits, and the role of religious faith.<ref name="ChampionAustin"/> According to ''The Intellectual in Twentieth-Century Southern Literature'', Godwin's characters "struggle intellectually to navigate the mazes of race, class, gender, family, faith and religion."<ref name="Powell 2012 p. 178">{{cite book | last=Powell | first=T. | title=The Intellectual in Twentieth-century Southern Literature | publisher=Louisiana State University Press | series=Southern literary studies | year=2012 | isbn=978-0-8071-3898-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zjnl_fyIt88C&pg=PA178 | accessdate=September 18, 2015 | page=178}}</ref> According to ''Contemporary Literary Criticism'', "she writes about issues pertaining to women - male-female roles, marriage, family, personal freedom, self-concept, and self-actualization."<ref name="twothousand"/> Author Jane Hill said Godwin's books are about co-existing with authorities, the role of decision-making in life, careers as an artist, and the consequences of thwarted ambition.<ref name="sixteen"/> Much of her emphasis is on the concept of the self<ref name="alpha">{{cite book | last=Xie | first=Lihong | title=The Evolving Self in the Novels of Gail Godwin | publisher=Louisiana State University Press | series=Southern literary studies | year=1995 | isbn=978-0-8071-1924-2 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iTOD5-XkaJoC&pg=PA32 | accessdate=August 19, 2015 | page=32}}</ref> and one's struggles with society.<ref name="sixteen"/>
Most of the academic analysis of Godwin's work focuses on challenges her characters have as women.<ref name="one"/> According to ''Contemporary Fiction Writers of the South'', a typical protagonist in Godwin's novels is a young woman that "in search of herself, confronts obstacles caused by her family, her lovers, her husband, or her own inanition as she struggles to establish her independence and secure her identity through her work."<ref name="Flora 1993 p. ">{{cite book | last=Flora | first=Joseph | title=Contemporary fiction writers of the South : a bio-bibliographical sourcebook | publisher=Greenwood Press | location=Westport, Conn | year=1993 | isbn=0-313-28764-3 | page=}}</ref> The main character may be personally flawed, then achieve self-reflection or personal growth thanks to the support of their community or a mentor.<ref name="two"/> Main characters often make poor choices, but become a better person, learn to make better decisions and build stronger bonds often as a result of intellectual pursuits.<ref name="Powell 2012 p. 178"/> According to critic Anne Cheney, the protagonist may be "searching for happiness, academic or artistic achievement, love, respect, or, more generally, meaning in life."<ref name="Emerick 2001 pp. 134–145"/>
According to [[Warren French]] from the [[University of Wales]], Godwin's works are most often seen as having two primary themes: gender roles and southern settings. French said Godwin herself disapproves of being categorized, which she feels creates "externally imposed limitations" on the themes she covers.<ref name="sixteen"/> However scholars continue to attempt to put her work into a distinctive literary category.<ref name="ChampionAustin"/> In her early works Godwin was seen as a "woman" writer, because her books appealed to a mostly female audience and because she is a woman.<ref name="sixteen"/> After publishing ''A Southern Family'' she began being identified as a southern writer.<ref name="sixteen"/><ref name="Powell 2012 p. 178"/> According to ''[[The Times]]'' (London), Godwin has a "pesky resistance to categorisation" and she often changes themes even after being commercially successful with one.<ref name="Katsoulis 2013">{{cite web | last=Katsoulis | first=Melissa | title=Flora: A Novel by Gail Godwin | website=The Times | date=July 20, 2013 | url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/arts/books/fiction/article3820012.ece | accessdate=September 2, 2015}}</ref> Academic Lihong Xie said Godwin could be identified with the literary tradition of the [[Bildungsroman]], which focuses on the moral and psychological development of a character.<ref name="LSU Press">{{cite web | title=The History of Southern Women's Literature | website=LSU Press |first1=Carolyn|last1=Perry|first2=Mary|last2=Weaks-Baxter| url=http://lsupress.org/books/detail/the-history-of-southern-women-s-literature/ | accessdate=August 25, 2015|pages=545–549}}</ref> Many other critics posit that a quest for meaning and self-identification are Godwin's primary themes.<ref name="Emerick 2001 pp. 134–145">{{cite journal | last=Emerick | first=Ron | title=Theo and the Road to Sainthood in Gail Godwin | journal=The Southern Literary Journal | publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press | volume=33 | issue=2 | year=2001 | pages=134–145 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1353/slj.2001.0004 | doi=10.1353/slj.2001.0004 | accessdate=September 18, 2015}}</ref>
Other themes in Godwin's work have included escaping the cultural expectations of becoming a "southern lady,"<ref name="Kissel 1996 p. "/> childhood abandonment,<ref name="twelve"/><ref name="eleven">{{cite news|title=A Woman Searches for the True Clear Light in a Multi-Hued World|newspaper=The News & Observer|date=March 14, 1999}}</ref> depression and suicide,<ref name="two"/> racial discrimination, social class<ref name="one"/> and succeeding without a male companion.<ref name="one"/> Her work has spanned different literary categories, such as realism, fantasy and allegory.<ref name="journal">{{cite journal |last=Chithraleka |first=D. |last2= |first2= |date=January 1, 2007 |url=http://worldlitonline.net/jan-07/Jan2007_8.pdf|title=The Portrayal of Women in the Novels of Gail Godwin |journal=The Indian Review of World Literature in English |publisher= |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages= |doi= |accessdate=September 18, 2015}}</ref>
===Early works=== All of Godwin's books written from 1970 to 1990 are fictional stories based on themes taken from Godwin's life.<ref name="Matuz 1999 p. ">{{cite book | last=Matuz | first=Roger | title=Contemporary Southern Writers | publisher=St. James Press | location=Detroit | year=1999 | isbn=1-55862-370-1 | page=}}</ref> Her early works focus on women hoping for a relationship with a male companion, but at the same time wanting independence and freedom.<ref name="sixteen"/> The main protagonist is often restricted by family, tradition<ref name="ten"/> and patriarchy.<ref name="alpha"/> Most of Godwin's early works include a prominent mother-daughter relationship as well.<ref name="sixteen"/>
Her first three books, ''The Perfectionists'' (1970), ''Glass People'' (1972) and ''The Odd Woman'' (1974), have protagonists who find that their relationship with a male companion restricts their personal and professional development.<ref name="Matuz 1999 p. "/> The first two books are each about a female character who feels trapped in an unhappy marriage.<ref name="Flora 2006 p. ">{{cite book | last=Flora | first=Joseph | title=Southern Writers a New Biographical Dictionary | publisher=Louisiana State University Press | location=Baton Rouge | year=2006 | isbn=0-8071-3123-7 | page=161}}</ref> According to ''Contemporary Southern Writers'', "unlike fairy tale romances, these novels present a realistic depiction of feminist concerns and struggles."<ref name="Matuz 1999 p. "/> Lihong Xie comments that Godwin's protagonists are southern women that "caught between the ideal of southern womanhood and contemporary feminism, struggle to form a personal identity  ..."<ref name="LSU Press"/>
''Violet Clay'' (1978) and ''A Mother and Two Daughters'' (1982) are each about an unmarried protagonist's career in a creative profession.<ref name="one"/><ref name="two"/><ref name="ten">{{cite news|title=Novelist Gail Godwin Takes up Story of a Woman's Spiritual Quest|first=Dale|last=Neal|newspaper=Asheville Citizen-Times|date=March 13, 1999}}</ref><ref name="Flora 2006 p. "/> In ''A Mother and Two Daughters'' the main character resists the temptation to get married and chooses instead to focus on her work.<ref name="one"/><ref name="two"/> ''A Mother and Two Daughters'' and ''A Southern Family'' (1987) each depend heavily on a southern setting and employ themes traditionally associated with social problems in the South. Some of their themes include racial discrimination, social-economic class and the cultural differences between generations.<ref name="one"/> Many characters struggle to reduce the gap between the rich and poor or try to break free from a dominant cultural tradition, with mixed success.<ref name="one"/>
In Godwin's early books, the female protagonists tend to be fearful, passive and repeat their mistakes.<ref name="Kissel 1996 p. ">{{cite book | last=Kissel | first=Susan | title=Moving on : The Heroines of Shirley Ann Grau, Anne Tyler, and Gail Godwin | publisher=Bowling Green State University Popular Press | location=Bowling Green, OH | year=1996 | isbn=0-87972-712-8 | page=}}</ref> The protagonist is often depicted as a victim who has failed to achieve independence and is struggling to form a personal identity that could exist beyond that of their relationship with a male companion.<ref name="LSU Press"/> In her next books, Godwin begins to introduce stronger and more independent central characters.<ref name="one"/> ''Violet Clay'' (1978) for example, features a more assertive character than those in prior novels.<ref name="one"/><ref name="two"/> According to Susan S. Kissel Adams from [[Northern Kentucky University]], Godwin's later characters:<ref name="Kissel 1996 p. "/>
<blockquote>come to value inclusion and connection over exclusion and isolation in their lives. They seek ways to combine their private and their public selves, open and extend family structures, take political action, and fulfill their social responsibilities  ... In their struggle against southern codes and family structures that retain a powerful hold even in the late twentieth century. Godwin's daughters of the South grow from a state of dependency and arrested development: they begin to embark on mature, adult lives of their own.</blockquote>
===Later works=== As in her earlier novels, Godwin's work in the 1970s and 1980s still centers mostly on difficulties female characters experienced as women.<ref name="Flora 2006 p. "/> However, she departs from this theme in ''The Finishing School'' (1984), which is about two women of different generations and the student-mentor relationship between them, rather than their relationship with men.<ref name="Matuz 1999 p. "/> According to Lihong Xie, Godwin's work during this period continues to be about "the female self" and a woman's intimate relationships with husbands, fathers and God.<ref name="LSU Press"/>
Godwin's books begin to incorporate religious themes starting with ''Father Melancholy's Daughter'' (1991). The novel is told from the perspective of multiple characters, each of whom have a different perspective on religion.<ref name="Emerick 2001 pp. 134–145"/> ''Father Melancholy's Daughter'' was followed by several books that centered on the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal]] church and Christian practices. In these novels female and male characters have a more equal influence on the events and plot than in prior novels.<ref name="twelve"/><ref name="Flora 2006 p. "/> Godwin's books neither evangelize nor mock the practices of the Episcopal Church, but rather treat it as a routine aspect of life,<ref name="Kissel 1996 p. "/> or as a subject of intellectual interest.<ref name="Emerick 2001 pp. 134–145"/> During these years Godwin's books continued to show father figures who have died or are absent. By 1996 two of her books had fathers that died and five had stepfathers that are depicted as intruding on the mother-daughter relationship.<ref name="Kissel 1996 p. "/>
According to ''Narrative Magazine'', Godwin transitions from female protagonists who are "looking for ways to get out of traps and confinements" to those who make "interesting or dangerous life choices."<ref name="Narrative Magazine 2009"/> Some of Godwin's later works depict successful, but unconventional marriages. In ''The Good Husband'' (1994) both partners accept the wife's career as having a priority over the husband's.<ref name="ChampionAustin"/> ''The Good Husband'' is also a return to the theme of marriage that is typical of some of Godwin's earlier works.<ref name="twothousand"/> According to ''Contemporary Southern Writers'', ''The Good Husband'' "explores the dying experience."<ref name="Matuz 1999 p. "/> Godwin also published several non-fiction works based on her own life during this period.<ref name="Narrative Magazine 2009"/>
Godwin's short story collections ''Dream Children'' and ''Mr. Bedford and the Muses'' focus on themes similar to those in her novels, but also incorporate dreams and myth.<ref name="Matuz 1999 p. "/> They tend to be less auto-biographical than her novels.<ref name="ChampionAustin"/> According to philosopher [[Anna-Teresa Tymieniecka]], Godwin's approach to dream-worlds is radical, because the dream is incorporated into the characters' real-world experiences. Her characters compare their real and dream worlds to each other in order to "negotiate their sense of destiny." She said ''Dream Children'' challenges the distinction between reality and dream experiences, where the dream does not "violate one's theory of reality."<ref name="springerone">{{cite book|last=Tymieniecka |first=Anna-Teresa |date=2009 |title=Existence, Historical Fabulation, Destiny |url= |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-1-4020-9801-7}}<!--|accessdate=September 18, 2015--></ref>
''[[USA Today]]'' said that the subjects covered in ''Unfinished Desires'' (2010) include "Mean girls. Lesbian kisses. Learning disabilities. Domestic violence. Alcoholism. [and] Roman Catholic nuns."<ref name="USA TODAY 2013">{{cite web | title=Godwin's 'Unfinished Desires' is only halfway done | website=USA TODAY | date=June 28, 2013 |first=Deirdre|last=Donahue|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/books/2013/06/28/godwins-unfinished-desires-is-only-halfway-done/2469473/ | accessdate=August 24, 2015}}</ref> According to ''The Times'' (London), ''Flora'' (2013) "encompasses most of the themes that have preoccupied [Godwin] throughout her career." It takes place in the South in the mid-1940s in the mountains, where a widowed schoolmaster raises his ten-year-old daughter.<ref name="Katsoulis 2013"/> In a 2015 interview, Godwin says that her work has become less "angry". She said her early works showed a frustration with not being heard, and that her later books focuses on her enemies. Now she's working to understand "the villains' villains."<ref name="Piepenbring 2015">{{cite web | last=Piepenbring | first=Dan | title=People and Rooms: An Interview with Gail Godwin | website=The Paris Review | date=April 10, 2015 | url=http://www.theparisreview.org/blog/2015/04/10/people-and-rooms-an-interview-with-gail-godwin/ | accessdate=August 20, 2015}}</ref>
==Reception== By 1980 Godwin's writing had become the subject of essays, book chapters and other literary analysis from academic critics.<ref name="one"/> According to ''[[The Washington Post]]'', "Gail Godwin has been accused of not being able to decide whether she's a popular or a literary writer, but she's certainly accrued enough bestsellers and literary honors to claim both identities."<ref name="Sayers 2010">{{cite web | last=Sayers | first=Valerie | title=Book World reviews Gail Godwin's 'Unfinished Desires' | website=Washington Post | date=January 19, 2010 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/01/18/AR2010011803350.html | accessdate=September 19, 2015}}</ref> Much of the scholarly attention on her works comes from those critics with an interest in southern or feminist authors.<ref name="ChampionAustin"/> According to ''Contemporary Fiction Writers of the South'', Godwin's books have been "widely and favorably reviewed".<ref name="one"/> ''Contemporary American Women Fiction Writers'' states that "although some reviews of her work have been mixed  ... her books are accomplished works of fiction, if not masterpieces."<ref name="ChampionAustin"/>
''Contemporary Literary Criticism'' said "most of her books are characterized as well-written, well executed, readable, witty, and having vivid, believable characters.<ref name="twothousand">{{cite book | last=White | first=Tim | title=Contemporary Literary Criticism | publisher=Cengage Gale | location=Farmington Hills | year=2000 | isbn=0-7876-3200-7 | pages=115–171}}</ref> Godwin is typically praised for having convincing plots,<ref name="ChampionAustin"/> witty, intelligent characters and that she has strong narrative skill.<ref name="one"/> She has been criticized, in particular in response to ''The Good Husband'', for excessive symbolism.<ref name="ChampionAustin"/> According to the ''Dictionary of Literary Biography'', Godwin is "thoughtful and philosophical", but she is often critiqued for authoring fiction that is so closely representative of her own life.<ref name="two"/>
''The Odd Woman'', ''The Finishing School'' and ''Southern Family'' received overall positive reviews, while ''Violet Clay'' and ''The Good Husband'' received more negative reviews.<ref name="twothousand"/> According to ''[[The Boston Globe]]'', ''Flora'' was one of Godwin's best books.<ref name="Miner 2013">{{cite web | last=Miner | first=Valerie | title='Flora' by Gail Godwin | website=BostonGlobe.com | date=May 5, 2013 | url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/books/2013/05/04/book-review-flora-gail-godwin/7aMXFUQF1CvbZHxjYnFdzL/story.html | accessdate=October 14, 2015}}</ref>
==List of works== This list of works has been taken mostly from Gail Godwin's entry in the [[Dictionary of Literary Biography]].<ref name="two"/> {| cellpadding=5 style="border:1px solid #BBB" width="700" align="center" |- | '''Novels''' * ''The Perfectionists'' (1970) * ''[[Glass People]]'' (1972) * ''The Odd Woman'' (1974) * ''Dream Children'' (1976) * ''Violet Clay'' (1978) * ''A Mother and Two Daughters'' (1982) {{ISBN|978-0-345-38923-7}} * ''Mr. Bedford and the Muses'' (1983) * ''The Finishing School'' (1984) {{ISBN|978-0-345-47226-7}} * ''A Southern Family'' (1987) * ''Father Melancholy's Daughter'' (1991) {{ISBN|978-0-380-72986-9}} * ''The Good Husband'' (1994) * ''Evensong'' (1999) {{ISBN|978-0-345-43477-7}} * ''Evenings at Five'' (2003) {{ISBN|978-0-345-46103-2}} * ''Queen of the Underworld'' (2006) {{ISBN|978-0-7393-2599-5}} * ''Unfinished Desires'' (2009) {{ISBN|978-0-345-48321-8}} * ''Flora'' (2013) {{ISBN|978-1-4088-4088-7}} * ''Grief Cottage'' (2017) {{ISBN|978-1632867049}} | '''Other works''' * ''The Southern Belle'' (1975) * ''Being on Everybody's Side'' (1979) * ''Becoming a Writer'' (1980) * ''Becoming the Characters in Your Own Novel'' (1982) * Introduction to ''The Best American Short Stories'' (1985) * ''Heart: A Personal Journal through its Myths and Meanings'' (2001) * ''The Making of a Writer'' (2006) * ''Publishing: A Writer's Memoir'' (2015) {{ISBN|978-1-62040-826-1}} |}
==Personal life== Gail Godwin lives in a large house in the mountains in [[Woodstock, New York]].<ref name="twelve"/><ref name="LSU Press"/> She does most of her writing in her study at home.<ref name="sixteen"/> As of 1999, she was swimming every day.<ref name="twelve"/> She has a southern accent.<ref name="sixteen"/> Godwin is an Episcopalian.{{Citation needed|date=December 2015}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book | last=Xie | first=L. | title=The Evolving Self in the Novels of Gail Godwin | publisher=Louisiana State University Press | series=Southern literary studies | year=1995 | isbn=978-0-8071-1924-2 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iTOD5-XkaJoC&pg=PA32 | accessdate=August 19, 2015 | page=32}} * {{cite book | last =Hill | first =Jane | title =Gail Godwin | publisher =Twayne Publishers | date =1992 | isbn = }} * {{cite book | last=Godwin | first=Gail | title=Publishing : a Writer's Memoir | publisher=Bloomsbury | location=New York | year=2015 | isbn=1-62040-824-4 | page=}}
==Notes== {{notelist}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.gailgodwin.com/ Official website] * [http://92yondemand.org/92ythe-paris-review-interview-series-gail-godwin-with-john-irving 92Y / The Paris Review Interview Series: Gail Godwin with John Irving] * Pia Z. Ehrhardt (Winter 2010).[http://www.narrativemagazine.com/issues/winter-2010/gail-godwin Gail Godwin, an interview] at ''[[Narrative Magazine]]''. * [http://www.nationalbook.org/authorsguide_ggodwin.html Interview with Gail Godwin] * {{worldcat id|lccn-n50-33169}}

revision.text:
'''Genocide education''' refers to education about patterns and trends in the phenomenon of [[genocide]] and/or about the causes, nature and impact of particular instances of genocide.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002480/248071E.pdf|title=Education about the Holocaust and preventing genocide|last=UNESCO|first=|publisher=Paris, UNESCO|year=2017|isbn=978-92-3-100221-2|location=|pages=18, 30, 34–35, 51–52}}</ref>
== Educating about genocide in Rwanda == Recent Rwanda history curricula explicitly stipulate the teaching of the [[Rwandan genocide|1994 genocide of the Tutsi]], notably through the comparison "of different genocides" with a view to "suggest ways of preventing genocide from happening again in Rwanda and elsewhere". A comparative approach has been adopted, which is clearly reflected in the 2015 Curriculum for [[Sustainable Development Goals|Sustainable Development]].<ref name=":0" />
The competence-based curriculum framework mentions "[[genocide studies]]" as a cross-cutting issue, therefore introducing the study of genocide in a variety of subject areas. It further states that "Rwandan children should know about the genocide perpetrated against the Tutsi alongside the Holocaust and other genocides".<ref>Rwanda Education Board. 2015. Competence based curriculum: Curriculum framework pre-primary to upper secondary. Ministry of Education, Republic of Rwanda. <nowiki>http://www.tcop.rw/</nowiki> le/2041/download?token=T398Bm6a</ref>
Teaching about the 1994 genocide of the [[Tutsi]] in Rwanda, and thereby introducing genocide studies in history textbooks and curricula, has been part of a gradual process to promote national unity and peace. This process included a moratorium on some chapters of Rwandan history in 1995, which ended when considerations pertaining to the 1994 genocide were introduced into the 2008 history curriculum. Recent approaches also built on the acknowledgement of the disastrous effects of pre-genocide Rwandan education, which contributed to discrimination against the Tutsi population and constituted a backdrop for the ideology that led to the genocide. In contrast, introducing the history of the genocide in the education system was a recognition that schools, in addition to non-formal and informal learning environments, are crucial venues to impart knowledge about the genocide and to overcome silence, denial and conflict. These changes also correspond to a deeper reflection on appropriate pedagogies to help learners grapple with the legacy of the genocide. According to Jean-Damascène Gasanabo, director-general of the Research and Documentation Center on Genocide at the National Commission for the Fight against Genocide (CNLG) in Kigali, "This change in the curriculum has been supplemented by a shift to transform learning from one based on standard rote memorization to one that encourages discussion and a spirit of critical thinking and analysis. This approach identi es the student as an active participant in the learning experience, not merely a silent recipient of history as 'evangelical speech'."<ref name=":0" /> [[File:Aegis Trusts Education about the Holocaust.svg|thumb|Aegis Trust's Sustainable Peace Model/Framework]] The [[Kigali Genocide Memorial Centre|Kigali Genocide Memorial]] and [[Aegis Trust]], in partnership with other Rwandan organizations such as the Educators' Institute for Human Rights, has developed education programmes and in-service training to help teachers build capacity and acquire historical knowledge to deal with genocides and mass atrocities. Such programmes emphasize "critical thinking, empathy and individual moral responsibility."<ref>Gasanabo, J.D., Mutanguha, F. and Mpayimana, A.. 2016. Teaching about the Holocaust and Genocide in Rwanda. Contemporary Review of the Middle East. Special Issue: Holocaust Education, Volume 3, Issue 3, pp. 329-345. <nowiki>http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/2347798916654583</nowiki></ref> They explore historical examples, primarily the genocide of the Jewish people and the genocide of the Tutsi, through a "Sustainable Peace Model/Framework" which seeks to link genocide education (looking back) to genocide prevention (looking into the present) to peace-building (looking forward).<ref name=":0" />
== Education about the Holocaust == {{Main|Education about the Holocaust}}
"Genocide education" deals with the phenomenon of genocide, while education about the Holocaust focuses above all on the causes and dynamics of the genocide of the Jewish people and responses to it. However, both fields are increasingly interconnected. [[Genocide studies]] – referring to academic research about the broader trends and patterns of genocide and mass atrocities – and genocide education have become more widespread in universities and schools, as genocide and mass atrocities are recurring phenomena in the world. The studies have expanded to examine theories about how and why genocide happens. Education about the particular event of the [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]] includes considerations about the concept, planning and implementation of that genocide, and can prompt reflections as to how what we learn about the Holocaust can contribute to the prevention of mass atrocities today.<ref name=":0" />
== The role of gender == Scholars and educators are increasingly recognizing and exploring gender as a dimension of genocide and other mass atrocities. Educators may wish to consider how gender influences, affects, and manifests itself in genocide, from the strategies of its perpetrators to the experiences of its victims.<ref name=":0" />
Historically, most atrocities have been committed by men. Genocide scholar [[Adam Jones (Canadian scholar)|Adam Jones]], however, notes that "when women, along with men, are mobilized, forced, encouraged, allowed to participate in genocide and other atrocious violence, they generally display no more reluctance than (often reluctant) males". [[Wendy Lower]], for example, studied the role of German women during the [[Nazi Germany|Third Reich]] and found that relative to their role in German society and their professional positions, women participated in the perpetration of crimes "as zealous administrators, robbers, tormentors, and murderers".<ref>Jones, A. 2017. Genocide: A Comprehensive Introduction, 3rd edition, Routledge.</ref><ref>Lower, W. 2013. Hitler's Furies: German Women in the Nazi Killing Fields, Houghton Mi in Harcourt.</ref><ref name=":0" />
Gender can shape and dictate both the experiences of victims and the methods perpetrators employ when committing genocide and mass atrocities. Roles often relegated to the female sphere can influence the fates of women. As traditional caregivers, for example, women who provide direct care for children or elderly relatives may inadvertently hinder or eliminate their own ability to survive genocidal violence. At the same time, perpetrators often differently persecute men and women. During the Holocaust, pregnant women and mothers of small children were consistently labeled "incapable of work". Consequently, women often found themselves among the first sent to the [[gas chamber]]s.<ref>United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, "Women during the Holocaust," <nowiki>https://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005176</nowiki></ref> Aggressors' intent on a symbolic and physical disruption of group reproduction often target women and girls for sexualized violence, such as mass rape or forced sterilization. Cases also exist in which boys and men have been systematically sexually victimized. Transgressions of gender norms such as homosexuality and transsexuality have also served as grounds for the targeting of both men and women.<ref name=":0" />
== Sources == {{Free-content attribution | title = Education about the Holocaust and preventing genocide | author = UNESCO | publisher = UNESCO | page numbers = 18, 30, 34-35, 51-52 | source = UNESCO | documentURL = http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002480/248071E.pdf | license statement URL = http://www.unesco.org/ulis/cgi-bin/ulis.pl?catno=248071&set=005900839D_3_308&gp=1&lin=1&ll=1 | license = CC-BY-SA IGO 3.0 | Editors = }}
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{other uses}} The term '''global village''' represents the [[approximation|simplifying]] of the whole world into one village through the use of [[electronic media]]. ''Global village'' is also a term to express the constituting relationship between [[socioeconomics|economics and other social sciences]] throughout the world. The term was coined by Canadian [[media theorist]], [[Marshall McLuhan]],<ref>[[Wyndham Lewis]]'s ''America and Cosmic Man'' (1948) and [[James Joyce]]'s ''[[Finnegans Wake]]'' are sometimes credited as the source of the phrase, but neither used the words "Global Village" as it is. According to M. McLuhan's son [[Eric McLuhan]], his father, a Joyce scholar and a close friend of Lewis, likely discussed the concept with Lewis during their association, but there is no evidence that he got the idea or the phrasing from either; McLuhan is generally credited as having coined the term. Source: {{cite web|url=http://www.chass.utoronto.ca/mcluhan-studies/v1_iss2/1_2art2.htm|title=The source of the term 'global village'|author=Eric McLuhan|year=1996|publisher=''McLuhan Studies'' (issue 2)|accessdate=2008-12-30}}</ref> and popularized in his books ''[[The Gutenberg Galaxy: The Making of Typographic Man]]'' (1962) and ''[[Understanding Media]]'' (1964) McLuhan changed the way the world thought about media and technology ever since his use of the word in his book <ref>http://www.cbc.ca/archives/entry/marshall-mcluhan-the-global-village</ref>. McLuhan described how electric technology has contracted the globe into a village<ref>McLuhan, Marshall. ''Understanding Media''. (Gingko Press, 1964, 2003) p 6.</ref> because of the instantaneous movement of information from every quarter to every point at the same time.<ref>McLuhan, Marshall. ''Letters of Marshall McLuhan''. (Oxford University Press, 1987) p. 254.</ref>
==Overview ==
Marshall McLuhan, who was a Canadian philosopher, invented the word in the 1960s.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Golovine |first1=Mila |title=Global Village: Where Cultures Connect |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/mila-golovine/global-village-where-cult_b_5035779.html |website=Huffingtonpost.com |publisher=Huffington Post |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref> McLuhan based his concept on the idea that cultures would focus on communicating and move towards personal interactions.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hendricks |first1=Beth |title=Marshall McLuhan & the Global Village Concept |url=https://study.com/academy/lesson/marshall-mcluhan-the-global-village-concept.html |website=study.com |publisher=study.com |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref>The term global village means different parts of the world that form one community that’s linked by the internet.<ref>{{cite web |title=Definition of 'global village' |url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/global-village |website=Collins dictionary |publisher=Collins dictionary |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref> Other forms of communication such as Skype allow us to communicate and connect with others, especially others in other countries, easier.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Yew |first1=Lee |title=The World Is Truly A Global Village |url=https://www.forbes.com/global/2012/0326/current-events-singapore-world-truly-global-village-lee-kuan-yew.html#1b4fc3187fc4 |website=forbes.com |publisher=Forbes |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref>
The new reality of the [[digital age]] has implications for forming new socially meaningful structures within the context of [[culture]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Essential McLuhan|last=Mcluhan|first=Eric|publisher=HarperCollins|year=1995|isbn=0-465-01995-1|location=Concord, Ont. : Anansi|pages=7–186}}</ref> Interchanging messages, stories, opinions, posts, and videos through channels on telecommunication pathways can cause miscommunication-- especially through different cultures.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0378720608000153|title=Cultural diversity and information and communication technology impacts on global virtual teams|last=Shachaf|first=|date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=|doi=10.1016/j.im.2007.12.003|volume=45|journal=Information & Management|pages=131–142}}</ref> Contemporary analysts question the causes of changes in community.<ref name=":1" /> Often they speculate about whether or not the consequences of these changes could lead to some new sociological structure.<ref name=":1" /> Most of them have pointed out that the increased velocity of transactions has fostered international density, making [[social network]]s a catalyst for [[social change]].
Across the global village people have reached out and transcended their neighborhoods. They are involved in a complex community of networks stretching across cities, nations, oceans, and governments. Yet at the same time the increasing communications with friends on [[social media]] may also increase the density of interconnections within already existing social clusters. The global village's implications on sociological structures are yet to be fully realized.<ref>''The Network Community: An Introduction to Networks and Global Village'', By: Barry Wellman</ref> Not only does multimedia have the ability to impact individuals differently for cultural reasons, but messages also affect people due to their religion, politics, beliefs, business, money etc.<ref name=":0" /> The time in which messages are received also affects how a message is understood.<ref name=":0" />
In Marshall McLuhan’s time, the global village was already apparent. It was already a comprehensive and seminal way to grasp what was happening to the world at large at any time (and correspondingly, what should be done with this in mind): "The global village absolutely ensures maximal disagreement on all points" (McLuhan: Hot & Cool. New York: The New American Library, p. 272).
During the primitive years, people primarily stayed in tune with the simultaneous mode of their perception and thinking.<ref name=":0" /> Today human society struggles neurologically, with the simultaneous mode taking the upper hand once again.<ref name=":0" /> Our brains are constantly adapting and morphing to the modifications of [[technological advancement]]s.<ref name=":0" /> Through technology, the creation of social media allows people to constantly comment on each other's posts as well as creating them to share with the multi-media global world. 55% of teens possess a social media account.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.medialit.org/|title=Center for Media Literacy|website=www.medialit.org|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref> Social media has connected people with jobs that they couldn’t have received before because of their geographic location.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mediacritiques.net|title=Journal of Media Critiques [JMC]|website=www.mediacritiques.net|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref> New social medias have connected the world so that users can learn more about cultures different from their own through interactions on social media as well as maintaining relationships from opposing countries.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rebecca|first=Sawyer,|date=2011-01-01|title=The Impact of New Social Media on Intercultural Adaptation|url=http://digitalcommons.uri.edu/srhonorsprog/242/}}</ref>
== Global village and media == People use technology to fit into a [[digital community]] to which they aren't physically connected, but mentally connected. Each [[social media platform]] acts as a digital home for individuals, allowing people to express themselves through the global village.<ref name=":0" /> A Review of General Semantics argues that media ecology and new media have expanded who has the ability to create and view media texts.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Valcanis|first=Tom|date=|year=2011|title=An iPhone in Every Hand: Media Ecology, Communication Structures, and the Global Village|url=|journal=ETC: A Review of General Semantics|volume=68|pages=33–45|via=}}</ref> Since mass media began, it has called for the westernization of the world, hence the global village. Without the mass media in effect countries like India or Turkey wouldn’t be living [[American way|American lifestyle]] because they wouldn’t have the knowledge of what the acquisitions of the American nation constitute. Since most of the developing countries acquired the news and entertainment from developed nations like the U.S, the information received is biased in favor of developed nations which connects the world in similarities within the media.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=M|first=Kraidy, Marwan|date=2002-01-01|title=Globalization of Culture Through the Media|url=http://repository.upenn.edu/asc_papers/325/|journal=Encyclopedia of Communication and Information}}</ref>
On the Internet, physical distance is even less of a hindrance to the real-time communicative activities of people. Social Spheres are greatly expanded by the openness of the web and the ease at which people can search for online communities and interact with others who share the same interests and concerns. According to McLuhan, the enhanced "electric speed in bringing all social and political functions together in a sudden implosion has heightened human awareness of responsibility to an intense degree." <ref name="UnderstandingMedia">''Understanding Media'', McGraw Hill, 1964, page 5</ref> Increased speed of communication and the ability for people to read about, spread, and react to global news quickly, forces us to become more involved with others from various social groups and countries around the world and to be more aware of our global responsibilities.<ref name="UnderstandingMedia" /> Similarly, web-connected computers enable people to link their web sites together.<ref name=":1" />
==Global theater== No chapter in ''Understanding Media'', later books, contains the idea that the global village and the electronic media create unified communities. In an interview with Gerald Stearn,<ref>Stearn, Gerald Emmanuel. ''McLuhan: Hot & Cool'' (1968), p. 272.</ref> McLuhan says that it never occurred to him that uniformity and tranquility were the properties of the global village. McLuhan argued that the global village ensures maximal disagreement on all points because it creates more discontinuity and division and [[Diversity (politics)|diversity]] under the increase of the village conditions. The global village is far more diverse.
After the publication of ''Understanding Media'', McLuhan starts using the term ''global theater'' to emphasize the changeover from consumer to producer, from acquisition to involvement, from job holding to role playing, stressing that there is no more community to clothe the naked specialist.<ref>McLuhan, Marshall and Nevitt, Barrington. ''From Take Today: The Executive as Dropout'' (Harcourt Brace, 1972) p 265 and back cover.</ref>
==See also== * [[Globalization]] * [[Information Revolution]] * [[Internet metaphors]]
== Notes and references == {{reflist}}
{{Marshall McLuhan}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Global Village (Term)}} [[Category:Globalization]] [[Category:Marshall McLuhan]] [[Category:Media studies]] [[Category:Postmodernism]] [[Category:Virtual communities]] [[Category:Community building]] [[Category:Cultural appropriation]] [[Category:Words coined in the 1960s]]

{{about|the environmental education organization|the video game|Laser Hawk}} {{Infobox organization |name = HawkQuest |image = HawkQuest logo.png |image_border = |size = 150px |alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> |caption = HawkQuest logo |map = <!-- optional --> |msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 200px --> |malt = <!-- map alt text --> |mcaption = <!-- optional --> |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = 1986 |extinction = <!-- date of extinction, optional --> |type = NGO |status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> |purpose = Environmental education |headquarters = |location = |coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> |region_served = |membership = |language = <!-- official languages --> |leader_title = Founder |leader_name = Kin Quitugua |main_organ = <!-- gral. assembly, board of directors, etc --> |parent_organization = <!-- if one --> |affiliations = <!-- if any --> |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.hawkquest.org www.hawkquest.org] |remarks = }}
'''HawkQuest''', founded in 1986 by Kin Quitugua,<ref name="animal_behaviorists"/> is an environmental education organization based in [[Parker, Colorado|Parker]], [[Colorado]], which uses participatory lectures including live [[bird of prey|raptors]] to help people "understand and appreciate the interaction of wild living things in their natural environment."<ref name="hq_main"/><ref name="hq_about"/>
HawkQuest has partnered with [[Xcel Energy]] to create classroom programs that use the bird cams deployed by the energy company.<ref name="creyete"/><ref name="birdcam"/><ref name="hq_lessons"/>
==Founder==
Kin Quitugua, master falconer and founder of HawkQuest, was born in [[Guam]] and moved to Colorado with his family when he was young. In college, he met master [[falconry|falconer]] Rick Cole, who took him on as an apprentice. After becoming a master falconer himself, he founded HawkQuest to teach others about nature with the help of his birds.<ref name="animal_behaviorists"/>
==The birds== As of 2010, HawkQuest had 28 individual [[eagle]]s, [[falcon]]s, [[owl]]s, and [[hawk]]s. The 15 species represented are [[bald eagle]], [[golden eagle]], [[American kestrel]], [[peregrine falcon]], [[prairie falcon]], [[barred owl]], [[burrowing owl]], [[barn owl]], [[great horned owl]], [[spectacled owl]], [[Eurasian eagle-owl]], [[Eastern screech owl]], [[ferruginous hawk]], [[red-tailed hawk]], and [[Harris's hawk]]. All of these birds are either injured or have been imprinted to humans and would not be able to survive in the wild.<ref name="hq_reptors"/>
==Programs== HawkQuest provides interactive lectures to groups of all ages, bringing the birds to schools,<ref name="apscms"/><ref name="broomfieldenterprise"/> nature centers,<ref name="cbs4denver"/> and other venues.<ref name="bbhc"/><ref name="steamboat"/><ref name="wild_bird_landing"/> HawkQuest raptors can be seen at close range at events such as Native American markets, renaissance festivals, educational symposiums, and craft fairs.<ref name="grapevinesun"/><ref name="hq_events"/> Their classroom-in-the-wild program takes students outdoors into the birds' natural environment.<ref name="hq_programs"/> They will set up opportunities for bird and photo enthusiasts to photograph the raptors in the wild.<ref name="photo_op"/>
In 2007, HawkQuest presented their message to almost 1.5 million people in 555 events.<ref name="hq_event_stats"/>
==References== {{Reflist |refs= <ref name="hq_main">{{cite web|url=http://www.hawkquest.org |title=HawkQuest |work=hawkquest.org |publisher=HawkQuest |accessdate=31 July 2010}}</ref> <ref |isbn=1-4108-0412-7}}</ref> <ref name="photo_op">{{cite web |url=http://www.douglas.co.us/openspace/documents/Raptorflyer.pdf |title=Raptor Photography at Spruce Mountain with HawkQuest
