revision.text:
[[File:Hen - The Swedish pronoun.svg|thumb|Visual illustration of the two gendered pronouns and ''hen'' by merged [[gender symbol]]s]] '''''Hen''''' ({{IPA-sv|hɛn:|lang|Sv-hen.ogg}}) is a [[gender-neutral pronoun|gender-neutral personal pronoun]] in [[Swedish language|Swedish]] intended as an alternative to the gender-specific ''hon'' ("she") and ''han'' ("he"). It can be used when the gender of a person is not known or when it is not desirable to specify them as either a "she" or "he". The word was first proposed in 1966, and again in 1994, with reference to the [[Finnish language|Finnish]] ''hän'', a [[personal pronoun]] that is gender-neutral, since Finnish does not have [[grammatical gender]]s. However, it did not receive widespread recognition until around 2010, when it began to be used in some books, magazines and newspapers, and provoked media debates and controversy over [[feminism]], [[gender neutrality]], and [[parenting]]. In July 2014 it was announced that ''hen'' would be included in ''[[Svenska Akademiens ordlista]]'', the official [[glossary]] of the [[Swedish Academy]].
It is currently treated as a [[neologism]] by Swedish [[manual of style|manuals of style]]. Major newspapers like ''[[Dagens Nyheter]]'' have recommended against its usage, though some journalists still use it. The [[Swedish Language Council]] has not issued any specific proscriptions against the use of ''hen'', but recommends the inflected forms ''hens'' ("her(s)/his") as the possessive form and the object form ''hen'' ("her/him") over ''henom'', which also occurs. ''Hen'' has two basic usages: as a way to avoid a stated preference to either gender; or as a way of referring to individuals who are [[agender]], [[genderqueer]], or those who reject the notion of binary gender on ideological grounds.
== Linguistic background == [[File:Gender in Pronouns.png|thumb|right|350px|Map illustrating the prevalence of gendered pronouns across world languages]] The [[Swedish language]] has a set of [[personal pronoun]]s which is more or less identical in form to that of [[English language|English]]. The common pronouns used for human beings are either ''han'' ("he") or ''hon'' ("she"). While [[Swedish language|Swedish]] and [[Danish language|Danish]] historically had the same set of three [[grammatical gender]]s as modern [[German language|German]], with masculine, feminine and neuter, the three-gender system fell out of use from the dialects out of which the respective [[standard language]]s were developing sometime in the late Middle Ages. The system contracted so that words of masculine and feminine gender folded into a ''common gender'' while the neuter gender remained. In Swedish, there are two words that would translate to the English pronoun "it": ''den'' for common gender words and ''det'' for neuter gender words. Both are gender-neutral in the sense of not referring to male or female, but they are not used to refer to human beings except in specific circumstances.<ref>Pettersson (1996), pp. 154–155</ref>
==History of usage== Attempts to introduce ''hen'' as a gender-neutral pronoun date back to 1966 when linguist Rolf Dunås suggested it in the regional newspaper ''[[Upsala Nya Tidning]]''. In 1994, it was again proposed by linguist [[Hans Karlgren]] in the national newspaper ''[[Svenska Dagbladet]]'' as a practical alternative to more complicated literary alternatives.<ref>''[[Svenska Dagbladet]]'', 8 March 2012.[http://blog.svd.se/kultur/2012/03/08/%E2%80%9Dhen%E2%80%9D-foreslogs-av-sprakforskare-redan-1994-%E2%80%93-i-svd/]</ref> In 2007, the feminist cultural magazine ''Ful''<ref>See also the [http://www.tidskriftenful.se/index.php?m=ful&o=manifest official manifesto] by ''Ful'' regarding the use of ''hen''.</ref> became the first periodical to adopt a consistent usage of ''hen''.<ref name="Atladottir">Margret Atladottir, "[http://nojesguiden.se/artiklar/nar-konet-ar-okant När könet är okänt]", ''[[Nöjesguiden]]'', 29 February 2012. Retrieved 26 July 2014.</ref> By 2009, ''[[Nationalencyklopedin]]'', the modern standard Swedish encyclopedia, had created an article about ''hen'' describing it as a "suggested gender-neutral personal pronoun instead of ''hon'' and ''han''".<ref>''Språkrådet'', 15 March 2012. "[http://www.sprakradet.se/13119 Hen inte nytt i Nationalencyklopedin] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130129185836/http://www.sprakradet.se/13119 |date=2013-01-29 }}"; Nina Bahadur, "[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/11/swedish-gender-neutral-pronoun-hen-national-encyclopedia_n_3063293.html Swedish Gender-Neutral Pronoun, 'Hen,' Added To Country's National Encyclopedia]", ''[[Huffington Post]]'', 11 April 2013.</ref>
In January 2012, the children's book ''Kivi och Monsterhund'' ("Kivi and Monster Dog") by Jesper Lundqvist was published. The book consistently used ''hen'' instead of ''han'' or ''hon'' and sparked a lively media debate.<ref>Adrianna Pavlica, "[http://www.gp.se/nyheter/sverige/1.874481-sa-borjade-debatten-om-hen Så började debatten om hen"] ''[[Göteborgsposten]]'', 29 February 2012</ref> In the February 2012 issue of ''[[Nöjesguiden]]'', a Stockholm-based arts and entertainment monthly, ''hen'' was used consistently in all texts with the exception of direct quotes.<ref>Margret Atladottir, "[http://nojesguiden.se/blogg/margret-atladottir/darfor-anvander-vi-ordet-hen-ledare-i-nr-2-2012 Därför använder vi ordet hen]", ''[[Nöjesguiden]]'', 29 February 2012.</ref> By late 2012, the word had generated so much publicity that ''[[Hufvudstadsbladet]]'', Finland's largest Swedish-language newspaper by circulation, declared that "hen is here to stay".<ref>Matts Lindqvist, "[http://hbl.fi/nyheter/2012-09-19/hen-har-kommit-att-stanna Hen har kommit för att stanna]". ''[[Hufvudstadsbladet]]'', 19 September 2012.</ref>
In November 2012, Swedish linguist Per Ledin made a survey of the use of ''hen'' in a [[corpus linguistics|corpus]] of Swedish [[blog]]s. His conclusion was that use among bloggers had been rising steadily from 2009 to 2012 and that it should be considered as an established word. However, ''hen'' accounted for just 0.001% of total usage of personal pronouns.<ref>Per Ledin, "[http://pasvenska.se/hen-i-bloggosfaren-spridningsmonster/ Hen i bloggosfären: spridningsmönster]". ''[http://pasvenska.se/ På svenska]'', 28 November 2012.</ref>
The airline [[Norwegian Air Shuttle|Norwegian]] employed the term in an ad campaign in 2012 as a tongue-in-cheek provocation with the slogan "The businessHEN's airline".<ref>''Språktidningen'', "[http://spraktidningen.se/blogg/nu-debatterar-vi-hen-igen Nu debatterar vi hen igen!]" 11 September 2012. Retrieved 26 July 2014.</ref><ref>https://www.dagensmedia.se/marknadsforing/kampanjer/norwegian-vander-sig-till-hen-6132158</ref> By late 2012, ''hen'' began to see use in official documents in some government agencies. The [[hovrätt|Court of Appeal for Lower Norrland]] applied the term in a ruling on [[official misconduct]] by a police officer.<ref>''Språktidningen'', "[http://spraktidningen.se/blogg/hens-uppgang-har-natt-hovratten Hens uppgång har nått hovrätten]" 14 December 2012. Retrieved 26 July 2014.</ref>
''Hen'' appeared in an official political context for the first time in February 2013 when [[Minister for Gender Equality (Sweden)|Swedish Minister for Gender Equality]] [[Maria Arnholm]] used it in a debate in the [[Riksdag]], the Swedish parliament. In commenting on the debate afterwards, Arnholm described the word as "a practical way of simplifying" and "a smart way of developing language".<ref>{{cite web|author=Lova Olsson |url=http://www.svd.se/nyheter/inrikes/arnholm-lanserar-hen-i-riksdagen_7911126.svd |title=Arnholm lanserar "hen" i riksdagen |language=sv |publisher=Svd.se |date=2013-02-13 |accessdate=2014-07-20}}</ref> By 2013, [[Boden Municipality]] had adopted manuals of style to be used by their employees in an official context where ''hen'' was recommended "to avoid repetition of he/she in texts where sex is unclear or where we wish to include both sexes".<ref>Original quote: "för att undvika upprepningar av han/hon i texter där vi inte vet kön eller vill omfatta bägge könen"; ''Språktidningen'', "[http://spraktidningen.se/blogg/sa-funkar-klarsprak-i-boden Så funkar klarspråk i Boden]", 30 August 2013. Retrieved 26 July 2014.</ref>
By early 2014, ''hen'' had become an established term both in traditional media and among bloggers. The language periodical ''Språktidningen'' concluded that the instances of usage had gone from one instance for every 13,000 uses of ''hon/han'' to just under 1 in 300.<ref>''Språktidningen'', "[http://spraktidningen.se/blogg/sa-snabbt-okar-hen-i-svenska-medier Så snabbt ökar hen i svenska medier]", 18 mars 2013. Retrieved 26 July 2014.</ref> In late July 2014, the [[Swedish Academy]] announced that in April 2015, ''hen'' would be included in ''[[Svenska Akademiens ordlista]]'', the most authoritative [[glossary]] on the Swedish language. Its entry will cover two definitions: as a reference to individuals belonging to a specified sex or [[third gender]], or where the sex is not known.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=128&artikel=5925135 |title=Svenska Akademiens ordlista inför hen |newspaper=[[Sveriges Radio]] |first=Mina |last=Benaissa |date=29 July 2014}}</ref> In May 2015, ''hen'' was introduced in legal text (the driver's license law), in the self-ruling area [[Åland]], a part of [[Finland]] which is officially Swedish-speaking.<ref>[http://hbl.fi/nyheter/2015-05-25/756705/ja-till-hen-i-alandsk-lagtext Ja till hen i åländsk lagtext] HBL.fi (Swedish) 25 May 2015</ref>
==Recommendations== Although the [[Swedish Language Council]], the primary regulatory body of the Swedish language, has not made a specific recommendation against using ''hen'', it does recommend using constructions such as ''När kunden har fått hem varan ska den källsortera emballaget'', "when the customer has received the merchandise, ''it'' should recycle the packaging".<ref>Use of the pronoun ''den'' ("it") is determined by the grammatical gender of the word ''kund'' ("customer"), a word that belongs to the [[common gender]]. By contrast, words like ''barn'' ("child") which belong to the neuter gender would be referred to with the pronoun ''det''.</ref> The existing ''den'' is recommended instead of ''hen'' when referring to human beings in general. The Council also recommends against using the object form ''henom'' ("her/him") with the reasoning that it is too similar to ''honom'' ("him"), which undermines the gender-neutral intention of the word, and that the [[grammatical case|case system]] on which the form is based is a remnant that is no longer used in Swedish; ''hen'' is instead recommended as both the subject and object form (as in ''jag såg hen''; "I saw him/her") while ''hens'' is the recommended possessive form (i.e. "her(s)/his").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sprakochfolkminnen.se/sprak/sprakradgivning/aktuellt-sprakrad/granskade-rad/2014-04-30-hur-anvander-man-pronomenet-hen.html |title=Hur använder man pronomenet hen? |trans-title=How does one use the pronoun hen? |date=2014-08-25 |publisher=[[Swedish Language Council]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2015-01-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150529135120/http://www.sprakochfolkminnen.se/sprak/sprakradgivning/aktuellt-sprakrad/granskade-rad/2014-04-30-hur-anvander-man-pronomenet-hen.html |archivedate=2015-05-29 |df= }}</ref>
After the use of ''hen'' by the Minister for Gender Equality, and following a meeting of the [[Speaker of the Riksdag]] together with party representatives, the Parliament made an official announcement that ''hen'' should not be used in official government documents, but that individual members of parliament are free to use it in spoken debates and written motions.<ref>{{cite web|author=Nyheter  00.53 |url=http://www.dn.se/nyheter/sverige/riksdagen-bor-avsta-fran-hen/ |title=Riksdagen bör avstå från hen |publisher=DN.SE |date=2013-03-05 |accessdate=2014-07-20}}</ref>
==Debate== From an early stage, ''hen'' has generated controversy and reactions in media. In 2010, the early use of the word prompted reactions of ridicule and skepticism. Columnist Lisa Magnusson taunted it as a "mega-feminist piece of poultry",<ref>Lisa Magnusson, "[http://www.aftonbladet.se/debatt/kronikorer/lisamagnusson/article12094836.ab Hen – ett dumfeministiskt fjäderfä]", ''[[Aftonbladet]]'' 19 January 2010</ref> In early 2012, a series of interviews and articles about the use of ''hen'' in ''[[Dagens Nyheter]]'', one of Sweden's leading newspapers, generated widespread debate. Referring to young children as ''hen'' was considered especially controversial, sparking critical reactions from the general public, officials within public daycare and media pundits.<ref>{{cite web|author=Dalén, Karl|title=Starka reaktioner efter intervjuer om "hen"|url=http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/starka-reaktioner-efter-intervjuer-om-hen|accessdate=2014-07-20|publisher=Dagens Nyheter|date=24 February 2012}}</ref>
In September 2012, ''Dagens Nyheter'' issued a ban on the use of ''hen'' in its article on the advice of chief editor [[Gunilla Herlitz]]. As a reaction to this, journalist and programmer [[Oivvio Polite]] created the website dhen.se,<ref>A play on the [[URL]] of ''Dagens Nyheter'', dn.se, and its acronym "DN" which is pronounced {{IPA-sv|de: ɛn|}} in Swedish.</ref> a site that mirrored the content of the paper's online edition, but with all instances of ''han'' and ''hon'' replaced with ''hen''. An employee at ''Dagens Nyheter'' reacted by filing a complaint to the police against dhen.se for violating Swedish [[copyright law]], but later retracted his accusation when the newspaper's management proved unwilling to pursue legal action.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dagensmedia.se/nyheter/print/dagspress/article3535185.ece|title=Herlitz inför hen-förbud|publisher=[[Dagens Media]]|author=Dante Thomsen|date=2012-09-10|accessdate=2014-07-20}}</ref>
The most controversial aspect of the use of ''hen'' has been vis-à-vis young children, especially in public schools. [[Egalia]], a [[preschool]] in [[Södermalm]], an upper middle-class borough in central [[Stockholm]], had been at the forefront of gender-neutral [[pedagogy]], and quickly adopted the use of ''hen''. This policy sparked debate and controversy in Sweden and received widespread attention in international media in 2011–2012.<ref>Dave McGinn, "[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/the-hot-button/youre-a-hen-im-a-hen-gender-neutral-pronoun-gains-ground-in-sweden/article4107472/ You're a hen, I'm a hen: gender-neutral pronoun gains ground in Sweden]" ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', 13 April 2012</ref><ref>John Tagliabue, "[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/14/world/europe/swedish-school-de-emphasizes-gender-lines.html Swedish School’s Big Lesson Begins With Dropping Personal Pronouns]", ''[[The New York Times]]'', 12 November 2012</ref><ref>Marie-Charlotte Maas, "[http://www.zeit.de/2012/34/C-Schule-Kindergarten-Schweden Sei, was du willst]", ''[[Die Zeit]]'' , 24 August 2012</ref><ref>Soffel, Jenny. "[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/genderneutral-preschool-accused-of-mind-control-2305983.html 'Gender-neutral' pre-school accused of mind control]", ''[[The Independent]]''. 3 July 2011.</ref>
==See also== {{Wiktionary pipe|hen#Swedish|hen}} *[[Spivak pronoun]] *[[Gender-neutral language]] *[[Gender-neutral pronoun]] **[[Pronoun game]] *[[Feminist language planning]] *[[Lavender linguistics]] *[[Newspeak]]
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}
==References== * Pettersson, Gertrud (1996) ''Svenska språket under sjuhundra år: en historia om svenskan och dess utforskande.'' [[Studentlitteratur]], Lund. {{ISBN|91-44-48221-3}}, {{OCLC|36130929}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Ingram Olkin | image = Ingram Olkin (cropped).jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Ingram Olkin in 1986 | birth_date = {{birth date|1924|7|23|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Waterbury, Connecticut]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = {{death date and age |2016|04|28 |1924|07|23}} | death_place = [[Palo Alto, California]], U.S. | nationality = American | fields = [[Statistics]] | workplaces = [[Stanford University]] | alma_mater = [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]]
[[Columbia University]]
[[City College of New York]] | doctoral_advisor = [[Samarendra Nath Roy|S. N. Roy]] | doctoral_students = [[Larry V. Hedges]] | known_for = | awards = }} '''Ingram Olkin''' (July 23, 1924 – April 28, 2016) was a professor emeritus and chair of [[statistics]] and education at [[Stanford University]] and the [[Stanford Graduate School of Education]]. He is known for developing statistical analysis for evaluating policies, particularly in education, and for his contributions to [[meta-analysis]], [[statistics education]], [[multivariate analysis]], and [[majorization]] theory. ==Biography== Olkin was born in 1924 in [[Waterbury, Connecticut]].{{cite book|title=Contributions to Probability and Statistics: Essays in Honor of Ingram Olkin|author1=Gleser, L.J.|author2=Perlman, M.D.|author3=Press, S.J.|author4=Sampson, A.R.|date=2012|publisher=Springer New York|isbn=9781461236788|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=5nLrBwAAQBAJ|page=4|accessdate=2015-05-24}} He received a B.S. in mathematics at the [[City College of New York]], an M.A. from [[Columbia University]], and his Ph.D. from the [[University of North Carolina]]. Olkin also studied with [[Harold Hotelling]]. Olkin's advisor was [[S. N. Roy]] and his Ph.D. thesis was "On distribution problems in multivariate analysis" submitted in 1951. Olkin died from complications of [[colorectal cancer]] at his home in [[Palo Alto, California]] on April 28, 2016, aged 91.{{cite web|url=https://news.stanford.edu/2016/05/04/ingram-olkin-influential-stanford-professor-statistics-education-dies-91/|title=Ingram Olkin, influential Stanford professor of statistics and education, dies at 91|publisher=Stanford.edu|accessdate=May 4, 2016|date=May 4, 2016}} ==A spokesperson for the statistics profession: Honors and awards== Olkin was awarded the first Elizabeth Scott Award from the [[American Statistical Association]] for his achievements in supporting women in statistics. In 1962 he was elected as a [[Fellow of the American Statistical Association]].[http://www.amstat.org/awards/fellowslist.cfm View/Search Fellows of the ASA], accessed 2016-07-23. In 1984, he was President of the [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]]. Olkin is a Guggenheim, Fulbright, and Lady Davis Fellow, with an honorary doctorate from [[De Montfort University]]. ==Publications and editing== Olkin has written many books including ''Statistical methods for meta-analysis'', ''Probability theory'', and ''Education in a Research University''. Olkin's coauthors include [[S. S. Shrikhande]] and [[Larry V. Hedges]]. Olkin has written two books with Albert W. Marshall, ''Inequalities: Theory of [[Majorization]] and its Applications'' (1979) and ''[[Survival analysis|Life distributions]]: Structure of nonparametric, semiparametric, and parametric families'' (2007). In [[nonparametric statistics]] and [[statistical decision theory|decision theory]], Olkin wrote ''Selecting and ordering populations: A new statistical methodology'' with [[Jean D. Gibbons|Jean Dickinson Gibbons]] and Milton Sobel (1977, 1999). Ingram was Editor of the ''Annals of Mathematical Statistics'' and served as the first editor of the ''[[Annals of Statistics]],'' both published by the [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]]. He was a primary force in the founding of the ''[[Journal of Educational Statistics]],'' which is published with the [[American Statistical Association]]. Olkin was also an editor with the mathematics journal, ''Linear Algebra and its Applications'', and has been active in supporting a series of international conferences on [[Matrix (mathematics)|matrix theory]], [[linear algebra]], and [[statistics]]. ==Bibliography== *{{cite book | year = 2015|editor1-first=Amanda L.|editor1-last=Golbeck|editor2-first=Ingram|editor2-last=Olkin|editor3-link=Yulia Gel|editor3-first=Yulia R.|editor3-last=Gel | title = Leadership and Women in Statistics | publisher = Chapman & Hall/CRC Press | isbn = 978-1482236446}} * {{cite book | year = 1985 | last1= Hedges|first1=Larry V. | authorlink1=Larry V. Hedges | last2=Olkin | first2=Ingram | | title = Statistical methods for meta-analysis | publisher = Academic Press | location = Boston | pages = | isbn = 0-12-336380-2}} * {{citation|first1=Albert W.|last1= Marshall|first2= Ingram|last2= Olkin| title=A multivariate exponential distribution|journal=[[Journal of the American Statistical Association]] |volume= 62|issue=317|pages= 30–49|year=1967|doi=10.2307/2282907|mr=0215400}} * ''Inequalities: Theory of Majorization and Its Applications'' (2011) Albert W. Marshall, Ingram Olkin, Barry Arnold, Springer, {{isbn|978-0-387-40087-7}} * ''Inequalities: Theory of Majorization and Its Applications'' (1979) Albert W. Marshall, Ingram Olkin, Academic Press, {{isbn|978-0-12-473750-1}} * "A Guide to Probability Theory and Application" (1973), with L. Gleser and C. Derman, Holt, Rinehart and Winston. * "Probability Models and Application" (1994), with L. Gleser and C. Derman, Prentice Hall. * [https://arxiv.org/abs/0801.4221v1 A tribute to Marshall and Olkin's book "Inequalities: Theory of Majorization and its Applications"] ==References== {{reflist}} * [https://statistics.stanford.edu/people/ingram-olkin Ingram from Stanford University] * {{MathGenealogy|id=13647}} * [http://projecteuclid.org/DPubS?service=UI&version=1.0&verb=Display&handle=euclid.ss/1199285043 Ingram Olkin] ==See also== * [[Marshall–Olkin exponential distribution]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Olkin, Ingram}} [[Category:Presidents of the Institute of Mathematical Statistics]] [[Category:Statistics educators]] [[Category:American social scientists]] [[Category:American educators]] [[Category:Combinatorialists]] [[Category:Stanford University Department of Statistics faculty]] [[Category:University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill alumni]] [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:Stanford Graduate School of Education faculty]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Statistical Association]] [[Category:People from Waterbury, Connecticut]] [[Category:Mathematicians from Connecticut]]

revision.comment: Infobox company: fix bad parameter names
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|section=| {{COI|date=June 2017}} {{Notability|Corp|date=June 2017}} {{Advert|date=June 2017}} }}
{{Infobox company | name = JIRNEXU | logo = Jirnexu Logotype.png | type = Private | area_served = | key_people = Yuen Tuck Siew (Chief Executive Officer), Liew Ooi Hann (Chief Financial Officer), James Barnes (Chief Operating Officer), Lucas Ooi (Chief Commercial Officer & Head of Insurance), Cedric Viver (Chief Technology Officer, James Wong (Chief Business Development Officer) | industry = Financial Technology | products = | services = Online financial [[News aggregator|aggregator]], [[customer lifecycle management]] | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = 51 - 100 (2017) | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | foundation = 2012 | location_city = | location_country = Malaysia | location = | locations = | caption = | homepage = {{url|https://jirnexu.com/}} | dissolved = }}
'''Jirnexu Sdn Bhd (Jirnexu)''' is a Southeast Asian [[financial technology]] startup headquartered in [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.asia.finance/knowledge-vault/venture-capital-entrepreneur/malaysias-jirnexu-closes-series-a-with-us45-million-for-full-stack-fintech-software/|title=Malaysia’s Jirnexu Closes Series A With US$4.5 Million For Full-Stack Fintech Software|last=Yong|first=Dion|date=2017-03-23|work=Asia Finance|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en-US}}</ref> The company provides technology to help [[financial institution]]s manage different stages of the [[customer journey]]: marketing, acquisition, fulfilment and retention.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://e27.co/jirnexu-adds-us1-5m-series-aims-complete-series-b-early-2018-20170322/|title=Fintech firm Jirnexu adds US$1.5M to its Series A, aims to complete Series B by early 2018|work=e27|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fintechroundup.com/full-stack-fintech-provider-jirnexu-closes-series-35m/|title=Full-stack FinTech provider Jirnexu closes Series A with $4.5m - Fintech Roundup|last=Graham|first=Ben|date=2017-03-23|work=Fintech Roundup|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Business operations == Jirnexu provides banks, insurance and telecommunications companies with a full stack technology solution to help them manage the customer lifecycle from marketing through retention.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.banklesstimes.com/2017/03/24/jirnexu-closes-4-5m-series-a/|title=Jirnexu closes $4.5M Series A|last=Zerucha|first=+Tony|date=2017-03-24|website=Bankless Times|access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref> With a Southeast Asian focus, the company currently has both [[Business-to-business|business-to-business (B2B)]] and [[B2C|business-to-consumer (B2C)]] operations in Malaysia and Indonesia.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.digitalnewsasia.com/business/malaysians-dont-just-compare-they-want-buy-financial-products-online-report|title=Malaysians don’t just compare, they want to buy financial products online: Report|date=2016-08-25|work=Digital News Asia|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en}}</ref>
Companies working with Jirnexu include [[Citibank]], [[HSBC]], Standard Chartered, Alliance Bank, AEON, AIA, [[Zurich Insurance Group|Zurich]], Manulife, U4Life, BSN, [[RHB Bank|RHB]], and [[U Mobile]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name="crowdfundinsider.com">{{Cite web|url=https://www.crowdfundinsider.com/2016/05/86064-southeast-asia-fintecher-jirnexu-raises-3m-series-a-funding/|title=Southeast Asia Fintecher Jirnexu Raises $3M Series A Funding|date=2016-05-24|website=Crowdfund Insider|access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.startupworld.com/news/jirnexu-ready-to-fortify-digital-banking-services-with-3-million-fund/|title=Jirnexu Ready to Fortify Digital Banking Services with $ 3 million fund - Startup World|date=2016-05-24|work=Startup World|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.enterpriseinnovation.net/article/rhb-launches-chatbot-personal-loans-ringgitplus-1093532576|title=RHB launches chatbot for personal loans on Ringgitplus|work=Enterprise Innovation {{!}} Asia's Premier Business and Technology Publication|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en-US}}</ref>
== History & background == Jirnexu was formerly known as Saving Plus.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theedgemarkets.com/article/cover-story-accidental-fintech-firm|title=Cover Story: The accidental fintech firm|date=2017-06-16|work=The Edge Markets|access-date=2017-11-02}}</ref>
In 2012, former Citi banker Yuen Tuck Siew, together with James Barnes founded RinggitPlus.com, a comparison and application website for financial products in Malaysia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.asianentrepreneur.org/21863-2/|title=Yuen Tuck Siew, Co-Founder of Saving Plus - The Asian Entrepreneur|last=Ting|first=Henry|date=2015-12-23|work=The Asian Entrepreneur|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/technology/the-rise-and-rise-of-chatbots|title=The rise and rise of chatbots|last=Ramchandani|first=Nisha|work=The Business Times|access-date=2017-11-02|language=en}}</ref> The website was officially launched in 2013 to allow comparison of and application for credit cards, home loans, car loans, investments and insurance schemes.<ref name="Khoo">{{Cite news|url=https://vulcanpost.com/243832/financial-comparison-websites-malaysia/|title=7 Financial Comparison Websites To Help You Make Wise Decisions In Malaysia|last=Khoo|first=Jean|date=2015-05-19|work=Vulcan Post|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://themalaysianreserve.com/new/story/smart-money-siew-yuen-tuck|title=Smart Money on Siew Yuen Tuck {{!}} The Malaysian Reserve|website=themalaysianreserve.com|access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref>
In 2014, RinggitPlus.com merged with SaveMoney.my, an online portal that provides information on different credit cards, car loans, phone, travel and shopping in Malaysia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2015/09/consumer-portals-confident-us1m-revenue-tie|title=Consumer portals confident of US$1m revenue with tie-up|date=2014-11-25|work=NST Online|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en}}</ref> SaveMoney.my was founded by Liew Ooi Hann and Lucas Ooi in 2012.<ref name="Khoo"/> Following the merger, Saving Plus Sdn Bhd was incorporated while RinggitPlus.com continued to operate as a comparison website.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.digitalnewsasia.com/sizzle-fizzle/ringgitpluscom-and-savemoneymy-announce-march-merger|title=RinggitPlus.com and SaveMoney.my announce March merger|date=2014-11-25|work=Digital News Asia|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en}}</ref>
In 2016, Saving Plus rebranded itself to Jirnexu;<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/05/23/southeast-asia-financial-comparison-startup-jirnexu-lands-3m-to-expand-to-digital-banking-services/|title=Southeast Asia financial comparison startup Jirnexu lands $3M to expand to digital banking services|last=Russell|first=Jon|website=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref><ref name="crowdfundinsider.com"/> the name means “prosper” in Maltese.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/tech-gadgets/article/fintech-startup-saving-plus-rebrands-to-jirnexu-raises-us3m-series-a|title=Fintech startup Saving Plus rebrands to Jirnexu, raises US$3m Series A|date=2016-05-24|access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref> The company launched XpressApply, an online application and CRM technology as part of its business to provide financial institutions a channel to reach consumers digitally by handling banking product applications online.
Several [[venture capital]] firms have funded Jirnexu, including SBI Group, Celebes Capital, NTT DoCoMo Ventures, Nullabor, Tuas Capital Partners, Anfield Equities, Digital Media Partners, Gobi Partners, OSK Ventures International Berhad and private investor Steve Melhuish.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.financemagnates.com/fintech/news-2/fintech-crm-provider-rebrands-jirnexu-3m-series-funding-announced/|title=Fintech CRM Provider Rebrands as Jirnexu as $3m Series A Funding Announced {{!}} Finance Magnates|date=2016-05-24|work=Finance Magnates {{!}} Financial and business news|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bankingtech.com/777202/fintech-funding-round-up-23-march-2017/|title=Fintech funding round-up: 23 March 2017 » Banking Technology|website=www.bankingtech.com|access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.dealstreetasia.com/stories/68185-jirnexu-seriesa-dmp-68185/|title=Malaysian fintech Jirnexu closes $4.5M Series A round, kicks off Series B discussions - DealStreetAsia|website=www.dealstreetasia.com|access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref> In October 2017, Jirnexu reported having total funding of US$8.0 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2017/03/22/malaysias-jirnexu-raises-1-5-million-for-fintech-software/|title=Malaysia’s Jirnexu raises $1.5 million for fintech software|date=2017-03-22|website=VentureBeat|access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.techinasia.com/jirnexu-pre-series-b|title=Fintech solutions startup Jirnexu nets $2m in pre-series B funding|last=Ellis|first=Jack|date=|website=www.techinasia.com|language=en-US|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-02}}</ref>
== Financial products == The financial products available for comparison on the websites include [[loan]]s, [[credit card]]s, mortgages, saving accounts and [[insurance]] plans.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://smemagazine.asia/2017/02/insurtech-and-fintech-players-join-forces/|title=InsurTech and FinTech Players Join Forces {{!}} SME Magazine|website=smemagazine.asia|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/money/2014/04/15/should-you-switch-from-a-savings-account-to-a-fixed-deposit/|title=Should you switch from savings to fixed deposit?|work=Free Malaysia Today|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://www.techinasia.com/ringgetplus-jirnexu-malaysia-funding|title=How Malaysia’s top financial comparison site plans to dominate Southeast Asia|last=|first=|date=|website=www.techinasia.com|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref> 25% of the existing products on RinggitPlus.com are Shariah-compliant.<ref name=":4" />
== See also == * [[Personal finance]] * [[Financial services]] * [[Financial technology]] * [[Banking as a Service|FinTech SaaS]] * [[Customer lifecycle management]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == * {{Official Website|https://jirnexu.com/}} * [https://ringgitplus.com/en/ RinggitPlus] * [https://kreditgogo.com KreditGoGo]

revision.comment: /* External links */ ORES predicted quality: Start-Class article Start (2.82)
revision.text:
{{for|those of a similar name|Jonathan Blum (disambiguation)}} {{multiple issues| {{COI|date=March 2015}} {{autobiography|date=March 2015}} {{notability|Biographies|date=March 2015}} }}
'''Jonathan Blum''' is an American writer.
==Background== He was born in Philadelphia on June 3, 1967, grew up in [[Miami, Florida]] and currently lives in [[Los Angeles, California]].
==Career== Blum graduated from UCLA and the [[Iowa Writers' Workshop]]. He has taught fiction writing at [[University of Iowa|The University of Iowa]] and at [[Drew University]].<ref name=AJT/><ref name=RescuePress>{{cite web|title=Authors - Jonathan Blum|url=http://www.rescuepress.co/jonathanblum|website=Rescue Press|publisher=Rescue Press|accessdate=21 April 2015}}</ref> He has published [[short stories]], [[essays]], [[poems]], and a [[novella]].
==Fiction== Blum is the author of ''Last Word'',<ref name=AJT>{{cite news|title=Meet The Nationally Acclaimed Jonathan Blum, Author Of "Last Word"|url=http://atlantajewishtimes.com/2014/02/meet-nationally-acclaimed-jonathan-blum-author-last-word/|accessdate=29 March 2015|publisher=Atlanta Jewish Times|date=5 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=Wayne>{{cite news|last1=Wayne|first1=Teddy|title=Interview With Jonathan Blum, Author of Last Word|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/teddy-wayne/interview-with-jonathan-b_b_4538458.html|accessdate=29 March 2015|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|date=7 January 2014}}</ref> a novella, named one of 2013's "best books to give as gifts" by [[Iowa Public Radio]].<ref name=Lieberman>{{cite news|last1=Lieberman|first1=Randall|title=Author to discuss book at B'nai Aviv|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2014-01-20/florida-jewish-journal/fl-jjbs-blum-0123-20140120_1_last-word-new-book-first-book|accessdate=29 March 2015|publisher=[[Sun-Sentinel]]|date=20 January 2014}}</ref><ref name=Nebbe>{{cite news|last1=Nebbe|first1=Charity|title=2013 Book Gift List|url=http://iowapublicradio.org/post/2013-book-gift-list|accessdate=29 March 2015|publisher=Iowa Public Radio|date=25 November 2013}}</ref><ref name=ISWF>{{cite web|title=Jonathan Blum, instructor, ISWF|url=http://www.iowasummerwritingfestival.org/instructor/jonathan-blum|website=http://www.iowasummerwritingfestival.org|publisher=Iowa Summer Writing Festival|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref> ''Last Word'',<ref name="Lieberman"/> brought out by independent publishing house Rescue Press,<ref name=Press>{{cite web|title=Jonathan blum|url=http://www.rescuepress.co/jonathanblum/|website=rescuepress.co|publisher=Rescue Press|accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref> won critical notice from such journals as ''[http://www.iowareview.org/issue/volume-43-issue-3-%E2%80%94-winter-201314 The Iowa Review]'', ''Heavy Feather Review'',<ref name=Feather>{{cite news|last1=Feather|first1=Heavy|title=Last Word, by Jonathan Blum|url=http://heavyfeatherreview.com/2014/05/20/last-word-by-jonathan-blum/|accessdate=30 March 2015|publisher=Heavy Feather Review|date=20 May 2014}}</ref> and ''Pank''.<ref name=Clark>{{cite news|last1=Clark|first1=Jonathan Russell|title=Last Word by Jonathan Blum|url=http://pankmagazine.com/2014/10/21/review-last-word-jonathan-blum/|accessdate=30 March 2015|publisher=Pank|date=21 October 2014}}</ref> It was also reviewed in the [[Jewish Book Council]] book review <ref name=Wendt>{{cite news|last1=Wendt|first1=Jamie|title=Last Word, Jonathan Blum|url=http://www.jewishbookcouncil.org/book/last-word|accessdate=30 March 2015|publisher=Jewish Book Council}}</ref> and by ''The Writing University''<ref name=Callahan>{{cite news|last1=Callahan|first1=Hope|title=At the Reading: Jonathan Blum|url=http://www.writinguniversity.org/blog/at-the-reading-jonathan-blum|accessdate=30 March 2015|publisher=The Writing University|date=16 June 2014}}</ref> In November 2013, ''Last Word'' was an Editor's Pick at [http://www.newpages.com/ NewPages]. ''Last Word'' was also on the [http://www.spdbooks.org/pages/bestsellers/fiction/default.aspx Small Press Distribution] fiction best seller list for six months, November 2013 - April 2014.
Blum’s short stories have appeared in [[The Carolina Quarterly]], [[Green Mountains Review]], [[Gulf Coast (magazine)]], [[New York Stories]], Northwest Review, Other Voices, [[Playboy]], [[Sonora Review]], and [[Zaum]].
==Awards== Blum has won the [[Michener-Copernicus Fellowship|Michener-Copernicus Society of America]] literary award,<ref name=ISWF/> the [[Playboy Magazine]] College Fiction Contest,<ref name=UInews>{{cite news|title=UI in the News|url=http://www.news-releases.uiowa.edu/1997/december/hitsdecember97.html|accessdate=29 March 2015|publisher=University News Services|date=21 December 1997}}</ref> a [[Helene Wurlitzer Foundation]] fellowship, and a [[Hawthornden Castle|Hawthornden]] fellowship.<ref name=ISWF/>
The personal essay "May Be Habit Forming" was a Notable Essay in [[The Best American Essays|Best American Essays 2000]], edited by Robert Atwan and [[Alan Lightman]].
== [[References]] == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.litshow.com/091/rescue-press-roundtable ''the lit show'' interview]<ref name=Margolis>{{cite news|last1=Margolis |first1=Amy |title=Interview |url=http://www.litshow.com/091/rescue-press-roundtable |accessdate=29 March 2015 |issue=91 |publisher=the lit show |date=11 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402165225/http://www.litshow.com/091/rescue-press-roundtable |archivedate= 2 April 2015 |df= }}</ref> * [http://www.kcrw.com/news-culture/shows/bookworm/jonathan-blum-last-word KCRW interview]<ref name=Martin>{{cite news|last1=Martin|first1=Rachel|title=Jonathan Blum: Last Word. Weekend Edition Sunday|url=http://www.kcrw.com/news-culture/shows/bookworm/jonathan-blum-last-word|accessdate=29 March 2015|publisher=[[KCRW]]|date=6 February 2014}}</ref> * [http://digital.lib.uiowa.edu/cdm/ref/collection/vwu/id/3534 [[Prairie Lights]] reading]<ref name=Prairie>{{cite web|title=Jonathan Blum reading, Live from Prairie Lights|url=http://digital.lib.uiowa.edu/cdm/ref/collection/vwu/id/3534|publisher=[[Prairie Lights]]|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref>
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Blum, Jonathan}} [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles alumni]] [[Category:Iowa Writers' Workshop alumni]] [[Category:American magazine editors]] [[Category:American science fiction writers]] [[Category:American male novelists]] [[Category:Science fiction editors]] [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]]

'''June Yap''' is the Director of Curatorial, Programmes and Publications at the [[Singapore Art Museum]]. She was formerly Guggenheim UBS MAP Curator (South and Southeast Asia), Deputy Director and Curator of the [[Institute of Contemporary Arts Singapore]], and curating independently. During her residency at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]], as part of the [[Guggenheim UBS MAP Global Art Initiative]], she curated the exhibition ‘No Country: Contemporary Art for South and Southeast Asia’.<ref name=yapbio>[http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/about/staff-profiles/curators/june-yap "June Yap"], Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation</ref><ref name=aia>Vine, Richard. [http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/news-features/interviews/june-yaps-asia/ "June Yap's Asia"], ''Art in America'', March 22, 2013.</ref> In 2011, Yap curated the Singapore pavilion at the 54th [[Venice Biennale]], featuring work by Singaporean artist Ho Tzu Nyen, 'The Cloud of Unknowing'. She has also curated exhibitions for the Center for Contemporary Art in Tel Aviv, Institut für Auslandsbeziehungen (ifa) in Stuttgart and Berlin, and the [[NUS Museum|National University of Singapore Museum]], amongst others.<ref name=aia /><ref>Dickie, Anna. [http://ocula.com/magazine/conversations/june-yap/ "June Yap's Asia"], ''Ocula'', August 12, 2013.</ref><ref name=aptbio>[http://www.aptglobal.org/en/Curators/Page/223/Yap-June "June Yap"], Artist Pension Trust</ref> She received her MA in Fine Art at the [[University of Melbourne]] and her Ph.D. in Cultural Studies at the [[National University of Singapore]]. She is the author of ''Retrospective: A Historiographical Aesthetic in Contemporary Singapore and Malaysia'' ([http://gbgerakbudaya.com/home/product/retrospective/ Petaling Jaya: SIRD, 2016]).
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/about/staff-profiles/curators/june-yap Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum biography]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Yap, June}} [[Category:Art curators]] [[Category:Curators]] [[Category:Museum people]]

Commemorative Medal of Congo | spouse = {{marriage|Guldborg Noer|17 January 1931|}} | relations = [[Halvor Løken]] (brother) | laterwork = | signature = | website = }} '''Kristian Rikardsen Løken''' (31 July 1884{{spaced ndash}}March 1961) was a highly decorated Norwegian military officer who served in the Belgian ''[[Force Publique]]'' from 1907 to 1917, fighting German colonial forces in [[East Africa]] from 1914 to 1917, and went on to command a [[Norwegian Army]] infantry brigade during the 1940 [[Norwegian Campaign]] of the [[World War II|Second World War]]. In 1943, Løken was one of 1,100 Norwegian officers arrested and sent as prisoners-of-war to Germany, only being released after the German capitulation in 1945. ==Early life and education== Kristian Løken was born in the town of [[Elverum]] in [[Hedmark]] county, Norway. He was the son of [[smallholder]] Rikard Løken (1845–1909) and Gurine Syversen (1852–1902). Kristian had an older brother, [[Halvor Løken|Halvor]] (born 8 March 1876), who also sought a military career. He attended the upper section of the [[Norwegian Military Academy]] from 1903, graduating as an infantry officer in 1906. That same year he took his [[examen artium]].{{cite encyclopedia |editor-last=Barth |editor-first=Bjarne Keyser |editor-link=Bjarne Keyser Barth |encyclopedia=Norges militære embedsmenn 1929 |title=Løken, K. R. |url= |accessdate= |edition= |year=1930 |publisher=A. M. Hanche |volume= |location=Oslo |id= |isbn= |doi= |page=391 |quote= |language=Norwegian }}{{cite encyclopedia |editor-last=Barth |editor-first=Bjarne Keyser |editor-link= |encyclopedia=Norges militære embedsmenn 1929 |title=Løken, H. |url= |accessdate= |edition= |year=1930 |publisher=A. M. Hanche |volume= |location=Oslo |id= |isbn= |doi= |page=389 |quote= |language=Norwegian }}{{cite encyclopedia|year=1948|title=Løken, Kristian Rikardsen |encyclopedia=[[Hvem er hvem?]] |editor=Steenstrup, Bjørn |publisher=Aschehoug |location=Oslo |url=http://runeberg.org/hvemerhvem/1948/0343.html |pages=343–344|language=Norwegian |accessdate=9 August 2012}}{{cite encyclopedia |last= |first= |authorlink= |editor= |encyclopedia=Studentene fra 1903: oplysninger samlet til 25-års-jubileet 1928 |title=Løken, Kristian Rikardsen |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digibok_2012101206029 |accessdate= |edition= |year=1928 |publisher= |volume= |location=Oslo |id= |isbn= |doi= |pages=268–69|language=Norwegian }} After graduating, Løken was posted as a first lieutenant to the 1st Akershus Brigade. In 1910 he achieved a permanent position in the Norwegian infantry. He was transferred to the [[5th Division (Norway)|5th Brigade]] in 1911 and to the [[2nd Division (Norway)|2nd Brigade]] on 1 October 1912.Barth 1930, p. 391{{cite news |title=Officielt. Fra Statsraadet idag. |first= |last= |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digavis_aftenposten_null_null_19121004_53_504_2 |newspaper=[[Aftenposten]] |date=4 October 1912 |page=2 |accessdate=9 August 2012}} ==Belgian service and the First World War== Løken was declared [[wikt:supernumerary|supernumerary]] soon after graduation, and granted leave from the Norwegian Army in 1907. He then entered the service of the ''Force Publique'' in the [[Congo Free State]]. He would have three periods of service in the Congo in the coming ten years.{{cite encyclopedia |last=|first= |authorlink= |editor1-last=Bull |editor1-first=Francis |editor1-link=Francis Bull |editor2-last=Eskeland |editor2-first=Arnold |editor2-link= |editor3-last=Tandberg |editor3-first=Erik |editor3-link= |encyclopedia=Gyldendals store konversasjonsleksikon |title=Løken, Kristian Rikardsen |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digibok_2011082608023 |accessdate= |edition=3rd |year=1972 |publisher=Gyldendal |volume=3: H-L |location=Oslo |id= |isbn=8205002681 |doi= |page=3854 |quote= |language=Norwegian }} Løken was among a sizeable number of Norwegian junior officers who sought foreign service after being unable to gain paid officers positions in Norway. The [[Norwegian Armed Forces]] had trained a large number of officers in the lead-up to the 1905 [[Dissolution of the union between Norway and Sweden in 1905|dissolution of the union between Norway and Sweden]], officers that were no longer required once the crisis between the two countries had settled.{{cite web |url=http://www.khm.uio.no/utstillinger/kongospor/finn_kjelstrup_tekst.html |title=I kong Leopolds klær - Et 100-års minne |last1=Semb |first1=Ellen |last2= |first2= |year=2007 |work=Museum of Cultural History |publisher=[[University of Oslo]] |accessdate=28 July 2012}}{{#tag:ref|In total, 200-300 Norwegian citizens took service in the Congo.Morel and Morgenstierne 2002, p. 190|group=Note}} Along with other Norwegian officers, Løken was shipped out of [[Oslo|Kristiania]] in March 1907. His brother, then army captain Halvor Løken, bid him farewell at the docks with the words "It's a comfort to know that ill weeds never wither" ([[Norwegian language|Norwegian]]: "''{{lang|no|Det er jo en trøst å vite at ukrutt ikke forgår så lett}}''"), in reference to the unhealthy and dangerous conditions then to be found in the Congo Free State.{{#tag:ref|Some 20 Norwegian officers lost their lives as a result of their service in the Congo.|group=Note}} Løken's group of officers first underwent a three-month colonial training course in [[Brussels]], Belgium, before being shipped to the Congo.{{#tag:ref|Among the other officers in the group was the later [[Collaboration with the Axis Powers during World War II|Nazi collaborator]] [[Finn Kjelstrup]].|group=Note}} During his service in the Congo, Løken would periodically receive renewed permission from the Norwegian authorities to remain in ''Force Publique'' service.{{cite news |title=I dagens løb. - Kongofareren |first= |last= |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digavis_aftenposten_null_null_19130216_54_86_2 |newspaper=Aftenposten |date=16 February 1913 |page=5 |accessdate=28 July 2012}} Initially given command of a ''Force Publique'' company, Løken eventually became a battalion commander in the Belgian Congo.Viksveen 1992, p. 72 Løken was one 21 Norwegians to attain the rank of ''[[Commandant]]'' in the ''Force Publique''.Morel and Morgenstierne 2002, p. 202 He remained in ''Force Publique'' service after [[Leopold II of Belgium]] gave up his personal control of the territory in 1908 and transferred it to the Belgian state. Løken's first tour in the Congo lasted until 1910, when he returned to Norway. He went back to the Congo in 1911, staying until 1913, and had a final tour from 1914 to 1917. During his final years in the [[Belgian Congo]], Løken saw action as first a company commander and later a battalion commander in the First World War [[East African Campaign (World War I)|East African Campaign]], fighting the [[Schutztruppe|German colonial forces]] commanded by General [[Paul von Lettow-Vorbeck]].{{cite encyclopedia |last=|first= |authorlink= |editor1-last=Heintz |editor1-first=Anatol |editor1-link=Anatol Heintz |editor2-last=Vogt |editor2-first=Hans |editor2-link=Hans Vogt (linguist) |encyclopedia=Fokus: illustrert familieleksikon |title=Løken, Kristian Rikardsen |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digibok_2007050204035 |accessdate= |edition=2nd |year=1964 |publisher=Aschehoug |volume=3: I-mektighet |location=Oslo |id= |isbn= |doi= |page=404 |quote= |language=Norwegian }}{{cite news |title="Kongo-Løken" er 75 år |first= |last= |url= |newspaper=Aftenposten |edition=Evening |date=30 July 1959 |page=3 |accessdate=}} Amongst the battles in [[German East Africa]] where Løken fought was that at Ruakadigi in present-day [[Rwanda]] in January 1916.{{cite encyclopedia |last= |first= |authorlink= |editor= |encyclopedia=Studentene fra 1903: oplysninger samlet til 25-års-jubileet 1928 |title=Flood, Carl Gustav |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digibok_2012101206029 |accessdate= |edition= |year=1928 |publisher= |volume= |location=Oslo |id= |isbn= |doi= |page=96 |language=Norwegian }}{{#tag:ref|Several of the other Norwegian officers fighting on [[Belgian Army order of battle (1914)|the Belgian side]] were killed during the East African Campaign.Viksveen 1992, p. 70 One of the Norwegian fatalities in the campaign occurred in the battle of Ruakadigi, where Commandant Carl Gustav Flood was amongst those killed.|group=Note}} Kristian Løken left the ''Force Publique'' and the Congo in 1917 and returned to Norway on 12 November 1917. Due to his years spent in the Congo he was affectionately nicknamed "Kongo-Løken" by his Norwegian friends and colleagues.Christensen 1990, p. 16Hovland 2000, p. 92 During his final years of life, Løken received a pension from the Belgian state for his ''Force Publique'' service.Morel and Morgenstierne 2002, p. 196 ==Inter-war years== Returning to regular Norwegian Army service, Løken was promoted to the rank of captain in May 1918. Following his promotion, he assumed command of the 4th Company of the [[4th Infantry Regiment (Norway)|4th Infantry Regiment]], a command he continued to hold until 1930. In 1918 he attended a [[hand grenade]] course, in 1919 the Norwegian infantry shooting school, in 1921 a machine gun course and in 1928 a tactical command course. From 1926 onwards he served on occasion as an instructor at the shooting school. From 1929 to 1931 he commanded the First Company of the [[Hans Majestet Kongens Garde|Norwegian Royal Guards]]. In the period 1932–1933 he led the Norwegian Military Academy. He attained the rank of major in 1933, and colonel in 1939. From 1933 to 1939 he served with the [[6th Infantry Regiment (Norway)|6th Infantry Regiment]] in [[Hønefoss]].{{cite encyclopedia |last1=Berner |first1=Jørgen H. |last2=Aalheim |first2=Trygve |authorlink= |editor= |encyclopedia=Studentene fra 1903: biografiske oplysninger samlet til 50-års-jubileet 1953 |title=Løken, Kristian Rikardsen |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digibok_2016051948033 |accessdate= |edition= |year=1953 |publisher= |volume= |location=Oslo |id= |isbn= |doi= |pages=89–90|language=Norwegian }} In the inter-war years Løken wrote three articles for the military journal ''[[Norsk Militært Tidsskrift]]'', one in 1927 on the subject of basic military training and two in 1936 on Norwegians serving with the ''Force Publique'' in the First World War East African Campaign.Johnsen and Wasberg 1969, pp. 223, 328, 330 In addition to his military career, Løken worked for the [[Office of the Auditor General of Norway]] from 1920 to 1923. After his years at the Auditor General, Løken spent a year in France in 1923–1924, teaching Norwegian students at the [[Lycée Pierre-Corneille]] in [[Rouen]], [[Normandy]]. He had been a state authorised French language translator in Norway since 1920. On 17 January 1931, Kristian Løken married the [[Brandval]]-born Guldborg Noer (born 3 July 1886), the daughter of forest owner Arne Noer and Thea Hokaasen. The couple had no children. ==Second World War== By the outbreak of the Second World War in 1939, Løken was in command of the [[14th Infantry Regiment (Norway)|14th Infantry Regiment]] in [[Nordland]] county, a position he had held since 17 January 1939, when he replaced Colonel [[Carl Gustav Fleischer]], who went on to command the [[6th Division (Norway)|6th Division]] with the rank of major general.Fure 1995, pp. 80, 90, 225 On 16 December 1939, Løken assumed command of Norwegian [[6th Brigade (Norway)|6th Brigade]], after the brigade's previous commander Colonel [[Wilhelm Faye]] had been appointed chief of defence for [[Finnmark]] county following the outbreak of the [[Winter War]] between Finland and the Soviet Union. Colonel Løken was also appointed chief of defence for the mainland of [[Troms]] county in [[Northern Norway]]. In this command Løken carried out brigade-sized field exercises to prepare his troops for potential combat operations.Berg and Vollan 1999, p. 26Sandvik 1965I, pp. 54-55Hovland 2000, p. 62 Løken was replaced as commander of the 14th Infantry Regiment by Lieutenant Colonel [[Thoralf Nummedal]].Hovland 2000, p. 109 By April 1940, Løken was temporarily in command of the 6th Division's officer cadets, while these were deployed on winter exercises.Haga 1998, p. 252 Løken's headquarters were located at [[Bardu]] in Troms.Steen 1958, p. 176 ===Norwegian Campaign=== Following the [[Operation Weserübung|invasion of Norway]] and the [[Battles of Narvik|German attack on Narvik]] on 9 April 1940, by [[3rd Mountain Division (Wehrmacht)|3rd Mountain Division]] troops led by ''[[Generaloberst]]'' [[Eduard Dietl]], Løken was responsible for carrying out the Norwegian mobilization in Troms.Berg and Vollan 1999, pp. 45-53, 94 The first task Løken carried out, in addition to the mobilization, was using the forces initially available to him to block the German forces at Narvik from advancing into Troms. Maintaining control of the central army base [[Setermoen]] was vital for the Norwegian mobilization.Haga 1998, p. 30 The forces under Løken's direct command when the Germans invaded were an infantry battalion, a mountain artillery battalion and assorted support troops. In the evening of 8 April, Colonel Løken had been ordered to send his infantry battalion and a motorized artillery battery to Narvik to defend the town, but the transfer of forces was pre-empted by the German landing.Steen 1958, pp. 23, 59 In maintaining a defensive posture with almost his entire force during the mobilization stage, Løken came into disagreement with the top leadership of the 6th Division, which wanted a swift counter-attack against the Germans as soon as possible.Berg and Vollan 1999, pp. 425-426 Despite not mounting an immediate counter-attack, Løken did move troops forward to blocking positions further south than planned, as he saw it as important to stop the German advance in the [[Gratangen]] area.Lunde 2009, p. 262 Colonel Løken's more cautious approach to warfare lead to a deterioration of his relationship with the more offensive division commander, Carl Gustav Fleischer. On 19 April, Løken reported that the morale of the opposing German forces seemed to be faltering, and that most of the Germans appeared to be "below average" at [[skiing]].Lie 2000, p. 165 After completing the mobilization in his area of responsibility and stopping the German advances into Troms, Colonel Løken was in overall command of the [[Battle of Gratangen|early counter-attacks]] carried out in late April 1940 by the 6th Brigade against the German forces in the Gratangen area.Sandvik 1965I, p. 256Berg and Vollan 1999, p. 78 During this time, Løken first had his headquarters at Kroken in [[Salangsdalen]] in Troms, before it moved forward to [[Fossbakken]] in [[Lavangen]]. Løken personally commanded the central axis of the failed first Norwegian advance at Gratangen.Ramberg et. al. 1996, pp. 103, 107Andersen 1997, p. 170 During the attack the 6th Brigade greatly outnumbered the German defenders, with two infantry battalions with artillery support mounting a direct attack against the German positions on Lapphaugen, while another two battalions made a flank march to cut off the defenders. The frontal attack failed after Løken had hesitated in attacking and sent his units against strong German positions in a disorganized and uncoordinated manner. While the main attack failed, the flank march of the 1st Battalion, [[12th Infantry Regiment (Norway)|12th Infantry Regiment]] was counter-attacked by the Germans, the Norwegians suffering heavy losses and being routed.Lunde 2009, pp. 294-309 After the failed initial offensive, Løken severely criticized the commander of the 1st Battalion, 12th Infantry Regiment, Major [[Nils Christoffer Bøckman]], for having bypassed Løken's brigade command in order to receive permission to advance directly from the 6th Division, exposing his unit to counter-attack.Andersen 1997, p. 174 Løken's orders to the battalion had been to under no circumstance move down into the Gratangen valley, but stay on defensible ground.Den Militære undersøkelseskommisjon av 1946, 1979, p. 132 On 29 April 1940, the 6th Division was reorganized into two weak brigades, the three-battalion strong 6th Brigade under Colonel Løken and the slightly smaller [[7th Brigade (Norway)|7th Brigade]] under Colonel Wilhelm Faye. While the 6th Brigade was to follow a generally mountainous advance route against the Germans, the 7th was to attack along the coast in cooperation with French expeditionary forces.Berg and Vollan 1999, p. 139 The 6th Brigade carried out a hard-fought mountain campaign over the coming weeks, pushing the Germans southwards along the Swedish border.Haarr 2010, p. 241 During the advance ski patrols reported in late April to Colonel Løken that the mountainous [[Kuberg Plateau]], in the advance route of the brigade, was unoccupied by the Germans. Failure on the part of Løken to act on this information and seize the plateau allowed the Germans to occupy and fortify the feature on 7 May 1940, requiring heavy fighting a week later before they were dislodged.Lunde 2009, p. 420 In May 1940, Løken was relieved of command of the 6th Brigade, being replaced by the Lieutenant Colonel [[Ole Berg]]. Colonel Løken was instead appointed temporary chief of the 6th District Command (covering Northern Norway) on 7 May 1940, replacing Colonel [[Lars Mjelde]], who had taken sick.Haga 1998, pp. 94, 168, 252Sandvik 1965II, p. 51Berg and Vollan 1999, p. 233 The appointment was formally confirmed by royal resolution on 31 May 1940, at a meeting of the King and Cabinet at [[Storsteinnes]] in [[Balsfjord]], Troms.Nygaardsvold 1947, pp. 42-43 According to General [[Otto Ruge]]'s memoirs, the replacement of Løken as a field commander was motivated by a wish on the side of the commander of the 6th Division, General Carl Gustav Fleischer, to have a "young and aggressive" brigade commander.Berg and Vollan 1999, p. 256 Following his appointment, Lieutenant Colonel Berg led the 6th Brigade in successful offensive actions against the Germans.{{cite encyclopedia |title=Ole Berg |encyclopedia=[[Norsk biografisk leksikon]]|first=Tom |last=Kristiansen |authorlink=Tom Kristiansen |editor=[[Knut Helle|Helle, Knut]] |publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget |location=Oslo |url=http://www.snl.no/.nbl_biografi/Ole_Berg/utdypning|language=Norwegian|accessdate=11 August 2012}} The main task of the 6th District Command, which Løken led for the remaining month of the Norwegian Campaign, was to coordinate the efforts of the civilian authorities in Northern Norway in support of the needs of the Norwegian front line forces.Hovland 2000, p. 169 During Løken's time in command, the 6th District Command was initially based in [[Harstad]], then later at [[Moen, Troms|Moen]] in [[Målselv]], Troms.Hauge 1960, p. 185Lie 2000, p. 180 On 10 June 1940, the forces in Northern Norway capitulated, a ceasefire having been in place since 24:00 on 9 June. Despite having been on the offensive until 8 June, the Norwegian troops were ordered to capitulate after [[Allies of World War II|the Allies]] had [[Operation Alphabet|pulled out of Norway]].{{cite encyclopedia |last=Nøkleby |first=Berit |authorlink=Berit Nøkleby |editor=Dahl, Hans Fredrik |encyclopedia=[[Norsk krigsleksikon 1940-45]] |pages=206–207 |title=kapitulasjonen i 1940 |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digibok_2010113005006 |accessdate=11 August 2012 |year=1995 |publisher=Cappelen |volume=|location=Oslo|isbn= |language=Norwegian |editor-link=Hans Fredrik Dahl}} Before releasing the Norwegian officers from captivity, the Germans demanded that each gave their word of honour not to participate in further resistance.{{cite encyclopedia |last=Moland |first=Arnfinn |authorlink=Arnfinn Moland |editor=Dahl, Hans Fredrik |encyclopedia=[[Norsk krigsleksikon 1940-45]] |pages=314–315 |title=offiserer |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digibok_2010113005006 |accessdate=11 August 2012 |year=1995 |publisher=Cappelen |volume=|location=Oslo|isbn= |language=Norwegian |editor-link=Hans Fredrik Dahl}} Following the Norwegian capitulation, Colonel Løken worked on maintaining order and calm in Northern Norway in the transition phase to German occupation.Jensen 1956, pp. 153-154 Løken had been made the acting commander of the 6th Division in the demobilization phase, retaining a 10-man force of armed military police under his command until 27 July 1940. The military police officers worked on returning requisitioned civilian vehicles and organizing military depots.Austigard, Grüner and Julnes, p. 114 Once the tasks in connection with the demobilization of the Norwegian forces in the north were completed, Løken returned to his home in [[Mosjøen]]. In mid-1941 Løken moved to [[Oslo]]. In the period March 1942 to July 1943 he worked in Oslo's civil air defence. ===Imprisonment=== In August 1943, the [[Occupation of Norway by Nazi Germany|German occupying authorities]] carried out mass arrests of 1,100 Norwegian officers, suspecting the officer class of supporting the [[Norwegian resistance movement]]. Colonel Kristian Løken was arrested on 16 August 1943 and given prisoner number 913.Ottosen 2004, p. 462 He was first imprisoned at [[Oflag XXI-C]] in [[Ostrzeszów|Schildberg]] in the German-annexed ''[[Reichsgau Wartheland]]''. While interned at Oflag XXI-C, Løken shared a room with Colonel [[Johannes Henrik Schiøtz|Johannes Schiøtz]], with whom he had attended the Norwegian Military Academy close to four decades earlier.{{#tag:ref|Several other members of the Norwegian Military Academy class of 1906 were also interned with Løken in Germany, amongst whom were Colonel [[Gulbrand Østbye]] (who like Løken had led an infantry brigade during the 1940 Norwegian Campaign), Colonel [[August Emil Dessen Tobiesen]], Major [[Kolbjørn Knudsen]] and Major [[Georg Otto Lorange]].Schiøtz 2007, pp. 247, 280|group=Note}} Løken and Schiøtz were roommates at Oflag XXI-C from 6 January 1944 to 19 January 1945, when the Norwegian prisoners were sent on a one-week [[The March (1945)|forced-march]] on foot and by train to [[Oflag III-A]] in [[Luckenwalde]], Germany. On 24 January, five days into the journey, Løken was transferred to a hospital train carriage, suffering from ill health. The Norwegian prisoners of war remained interned at Oflag III-A until their German guards abandoned the camp on 21 April 1945, with Soviet forces arriving the next day. On 10 May 1945, two days after the [[End of World War II in Europe|end of the war in Europe]], the Norwegian prisoners left Luckenwalde, reaching Norway in several groups in late May/early June 1945.Schiøtz 2007, pp. 193, 307-323, 350-351, 375-423 Løken arrived in Oslo on 28 May 1945. ==Post-war life== From 1946 to 1954, Løken worked with the General Inspector of the Infantry, and until 1952 as a French language teacher at the Norwegian Military Academy.{{cite news |title=Obituary |first= |last= |url= |newspaper=Aftenposten |edition=Morning |date=7 March 1961 |page=15 |accessdate=}} In 1947, Løken also held the position as second in command of District Command North in Northern Norway. According to the Norwegian military intelligence officer [[Christian Christensen (editor)|Christian Christensen]], Løken's relationship with the commander of District Command North, General [[Arne Dagfin Dahl]], was poor. Løken was, according to Christensen, completely relegated from any meaningful tasks by General Dahl. Several years previously, during the 1940 Norwegian Campaign, Løken had been Dahl's commanding officer.Haga 1998, p. 53 On 1 August 1949 he formally retired from the Norwegian Armed Forces, yet continued working for several years under temporary contracts. Colonel Kristian Løken was the vice chairman of the reconstituted Norwegian Congo Veterans' Association ({{Lang-no|Norske kongoveteraners forening}}, {{Lang-fr|Section de Norvège des Vétérans Coloniaux}}). He remained a member until the association was finally disestablished in 1960, being awarded the society's 50 year medal (commemorating the disestablishment of the Congo Free State in 1908) in 1958.Morel and Morgenstierne 2002, pp. 153, 190-196{{#tag:ref|The original association, founded in 1939, had been disestablished in 1946. After exclusions of members who had committed treason during the Second World War, the association was reconstituted in 1947.Morel and Morgenstierne 2002, p. 193|group=Note}} By 1948, he lived in Oslo, Norway. Kristian Rikardsen Løken died in March 1961, aged 76. ==Honours and awards== For his services in the Congo, the Belgian authorities awarded Løken a total of 14 decorations. Among his Belgian honours, Løken was made an Officer of the [[Order of Leopold II]], a Knight of [[Order of Leopold (Belgium)|Order of Leopold]], a Knight of the [[Royal Order of the Lion]] and a Knight of the [[Order of the Crown (Belgium)|Order of the Crown with palm]], as well as being awarded the [[Croix de guerre (Belgium)|Croix de guerre with palm]], the [[Order of the African Star|Order of the African Star, Silver Medal]], the [[1914–1917 African Campaigns Commemorative Medal]], the [[Commemorative Medal of the 1914–1918 War]], the [[Inter-Allied Victory Medal (Belgium)|Inter-Allied Victory Medal 1914–1918]], and the Commemorative Medal of Congo. After the end of the Second World War, Colonel Løken was decorated by the Norwegian government with the [[St. Olav's Medal With Oak Branch]], the second highest Norwegian war decoration.Gjems-Onstad 1996, p. 202 He also received the [[Defence Medal 1940–1945]] and the [[Haakon VII Jubilee Medal 1905–1955]]. The French government made him an {{lang|fr|Officier}} of the {{lang|fr|[[Legion of Honour|Légion d'honneur]]}} and awarded him the {{lang|fr|[[1939–1945 War Cross (France)|Croix de guerre]]}}. ==References== ;Notes {{Reflist|group=Note}} ;Citations {{Reflist|colwidth=33em}} ;Bibliography *{{cite book |last1=Andersen |first1=Trygve |year=1997 |title=Varanger bataljons historie 1898-1995 |pages= |publisher=Finnmark regiment |location= |isbn=8299452309 |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digibok_2008081200055 |language=Norwegian}} *{{cite book |editor1-last=Austigard |editor1-first=Bjørn |editor2-last=Grüner |editor2-first=Otto R. |editor3-last=Julnes |editor3-first=Johan |year=1982 |title=Hedersskrift til Nils Parelius på 70-årsdagen den 24. mai 1982 |pages= |publisher=Romsdal sogelag |location=Molde |isbn=8290169078 |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digibok_2014081508254 |language=Norwegian}} *{{cite book |last1=Berg |first1=Johan Helge |last2=Vollan |first2=Olav |year=1999 |title=Fjellkrigen 1940: Lapphaugen - Bjørnfjell |pages= |publisher=Nord-Hålogaland regiment |location=Trondheim |isbn=82-995412-0-4 |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digibok_2010052003018 |language=Norwegian}} *{{cite book|last=Christensen |first=Christian |authorlink=Christian Christensen (editor) |title=Av hensyn til rikets sikkerhet - |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digibok_2010071408048 |year=1990 |publisher=Cappelen |location=Oslo |language=Norwegian |isbn=8202124476}} *{{cite book |last=Den Militære undersøkelseskommisjon av 1946 |first= |authorlink= |title=Rapport fra den militære undersøkelseskommisjon av 1946, avgitt mai 1950; revision.comment: /* Background */ tense
revision.text:
{{Infobox referendum | name = Question 2: Citizen Initiative | title = '''An Act To Establish The Fund to Advance Public Kindergarten to Grade 12 Education''' | yes = 383,428 | no = 373,848 | total = 771,708 | map = | mapdivision = | mapcaption = | notes = }} {{ElectionsME}} '''Maine Question 2''', formally '''An Act to Establish The Fund to Advance Public Kindergarten to Grade 12 Education''',https://www1.maine.gov/sos/cec/elec/upcoming/citizensguide2016.pdf was a citizen-initiated referendum question that appeared on the Maine November 8, 2016 statewide ballot. It sought to increase state aid to public schools by instituting a surcharge of 3% on Maine income taxes for those with income above $200,000 a year. As the [[Maine Legislature]] and [[Governor of Maine|Governor]] [[Paul LePage]] declined to enact the proposal as written, it appeared on the ballot along with elections for [[United States presidential election, 2016|President of the United States]], [[United States House of Representatives elections in Maine, 2016|Maine's two U.S. House seats]], the Legislature, and various local elections. The question was passed by roughly 10,000 votes. The surtax created by the question was repealed as part of state budget negotiations on July 3, 2017 that added $162 million to public education funding from general revenue. ==Background== In 2003, Maine voters passed a referendum calling for the state to pay for 55% of the cost of operating public schools, as a way to reduce pressure on local property taxes. That percentage has never been met.{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2015/07/10/business/maine-budget-deemed-credit-negative-for-cities-towns/|title=Moody’s: Maine budget ‘credit negative’ for cities, towns|publisher=Bangor Daily News|date=July 10, 2015|accessdate=March 12, 2016}} To attempt to reach that target, a group called Stand Up for Students announced that it would start a petition drive to implement a 3% surcharge on Maine income taxes paid on those with incomes above $200,000 a year, estimated to be the top 2% of earners in Maine.{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2015/10/07/news/state/group-proposes-taxing-top-2-percent-to-help-state-meet-education-funding-law/|title=Group proposes taxing top 2 percent to help state meet education funding law|publisher=Bangor Daily News|date=October 7, 2015|accessdate=March 12, 2016}} It is estimated that such a tax surcharge would result in $110 million a year in revenue.{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2016/03/02/politics/petition-to-force-more-maine-school-aid-clears-ballot-hurdle/|title=Petition to force more Maine school aid clears ballot hurdle|publisher=Bangor Daily News|date=March 2, 2016|accessdate=March 12, 2016}} The petition drive was carried out by some paid signature gatherers, but was largely done by volunteers from the Maine Education Association and the [[Maine People's Alliance]], a liberal organizing group. MEA members were offered $25 Visa gift cards for every 100 signatures they gathered.{{cite web|url=http://stateandcapitol.bangordailynews.com/2015/12/17/group-that-wants-maine-to-spend-more-on-public-schools-nears-petition-goal/|title=Group that wants Maine to spend more on public schools nears petition goal|publisher=Bangor Daily News|date=December 17, 2015|accessdate=March 12, 2016}} The office of [[Maine Secretary of State]] [[Matthew Dunlap]] certified that the proposal qualified for the ballot on March 2, 2016, stating that 66,849 signatures were valid. The exact wording of the question was disputed. Secretary Dunlap proposed the wording "Do you want to establish a fund to support kindergarten through 12th grade public education by adding a three percent surcharge on Maine taxable income above $200,000?". During the required public comment period before the wording was finalized, the [[Governor of Maine|Governor's Office]] filed an objection to the proposed wording, stating that the word 'tax' or 'surtax' should be used instead of 'surcharge'. Doing so, they stated, would have been consistent with prior referendums calling for generating revenue. A Stand Up for Students spokesman called the objection an effort to confuse voters, citing tax cuts enacted by Governor [[Paul LePage]]. Dunlap had until June 24 to make a final decision, which was only possible to appeal by going to court.{{cite web|url=http://www.mpbn.net/post/lepage-administration-challenges-wording-education-ballot-question#stream/0|title=LePage Administration Challenges Wording of Education Ballot Question |publisher=[[MPBN]]|date=June 13, 2016|accessdate=June 13, 2016}} Dunlap released the final wording of the question on June 23, which read as "Do you want to add a 3% tax on individual Maine taxable income above $200,000 to create a state fund that would provide direct support for student learning in kindergarten through 12th grade public education?" {{cite web|url=http://stateandcapitol.bangordailynews.com/2016/06/23/maine-secretary-of-state-revises-wording-of-all-five-november-ballot-questions/|title=Maine secretary of state revises wording of all five November ballot questions|publisher=Bangor Daily News |date=June 23, 2016 |accessdate=June 23, 2016}} ==Campaign== The Maine State Chamber of Commerce formed a PAC called No on Question 2 on August 2, 2016. Chamber President Dana Connors said that while they support strong education funding, it should be done in a manner that does not affect the economy. He went on to state that such a tax would discourage professionals from living in Maine.{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2016/08/02/politics/maine-chamber-of-commerce-forms-pac-to-oppose-new-tax-to-fund-education/|title=Maine Chamber of Commerce forms PAC to oppose new tax to fund education|publisher=Bangor Daily News|date=August 2, 2016|accessdate=August 2, 2016}} ===Notable endorsements=== ====Supporters==== *Maine Association of School Librarieshttp://standupforstudentsmaine.org/46-2/endorsements/ *Maine Children’s Alliance *Maine Education Association *Maine Parent Teacher Association *Maine Small Business Coalition *Machinists (IAM) Local S7 *Maine People’s Resource Center *Maine People’s Alliance *Maine [[AFL-CIO]] *Maine State Employees Association *Maine Center for Economic Policy ====Opponents==== *[[John Baldacci]], former [[Governor of Maine]]http://stateandcapitol.bangordailynews.com/2016/09/15/john-baldacci-opposes-education-tax-question-on-november-ballot/ *[[Paul LePage]], Governor of Maine *[[Stephen Bowen (politician)|Stephen Bowen]], former Commissioner of the Maine Department of Education *Jim Rier, former Commissioner of the Maine Department of Education *[[Maine Heritage Policy Center]]http://mainepolicy.org/the-wrong-choice-for-me-question-2-report/ *Maine State Chamber of Commerce *''[[Bangor Daily News]]''{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2016/10/15/opinion/editorials/with-question-2-maine-gets-higher-taxes-same-education-system-that-needs-improving/?ref=OpinionBox|title=With Question 2, Maine gets higher taxes, same education system that needs improving|publisher=Bangor Daily News|date=October 15, 2015|accessdate=October 16, 2016}} *[[MaineToday Media]] newspapers; ''[[Portland Press Herald]]'', ''[[Kennebec Journal]]'', ''[[Morning Sentinel]]''http://www.pressherald.com/2016/10/30/our-view-vote-no-on-question-2-make-augusta-fix-schools/ ===Polling=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:825px;" !Date of opinion poll !Conducted by ![[Sample size]]
(likely voters) !Yes !No !Undecided !Margin of Error |- | '''October 20–25, 2016'''http://www.pressherald.com/2016/10/31/margins-of-support-shrink-for-3-of-the-6-maine-ballot-issues-poll-indicates/ | University of New Hampshire | 761 | '''57%''' | 34% | 9% | ±3.6% |- | '''September 15–20, 2016'''http://www.pressherald.com/2016/09/28/support-for-tax-to-fund-education-splits-along-party-lines-in-survey/document/ | University of New Hampshire | 506 | '''60%''' | 32% | 8% | ±4.3% |} ==Results== Uncertified results indicated that Question 2 passed by a margin of around 10,000 votes. Due to the closeness of the result, opponents of Question 2 filed a petition for a recount, then withdrew their petition on November 29.{{cite web|last1=Carrigan|first1=Don|title=Petitions for recount on Questions 1 and 2|url=http://www.wcsh6.com/news/politics/voice-of-the-voter/petitions-for-recount-on-questions-1-and-2/352715558|website=WSCH6 Portland|publisher=WCSH-TV|accessdate=10 March 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Graham|first1=Gilligan|title=Group withdraws request for recount of education surcharge vote|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2016/11/29/first-of-2-maine-referendum-recounts-will-start-thursday/|website=The Portland Press-Herald|publisher=MaineToday Media|accessdate=10 March 2017}} {| style="width:50%;" class="wikitable sortable" |+Question 2 Results{{cite web|title=Tabulations for Elections held in 2016|url=http://www.maine.gov/sos/cec/elec/results/results16-17.html#tally|website=Bureau of Corporations, Elections & Commissions|publisher=Maine Department of the Secretary of State|accessdate=9 March 2017}} |- style="background:lightgrey;" ! style="width:21%;"| County ! style="width:10%;"| Yes ! style="width:10%;"| Votes ! style="width:10%;"| No ! style="width:10%;"| Votes |- | style="text-align:center;
